questions.text:
A woman presents with insidious onset, worsening exertional breathlessness, and occasional exertional chest pain. On examination, she has increased JVP, peripheral edema, ascites, and a loud P2. Her investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Chest X-ray - enlarged central pulmonary arteries and vascular pruning 

Echocardiography - hypertrophied right ventricle

ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

JVP: Jugulovenous pulse, STEMI: ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hypertension. 

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is characterized by an elevation in pulmonary arterial pressures and increased vascular resistance caused by various causes. It is defined by mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20mmHg

Clinical features include dyspnea, edema, chest pain, and syncope. It is irreversible as it does not have a curative treatment and thus can lead to decompensated right heart failure and death. 

Clinical signs may include right heart failure features such as elevated JVP, edema, ascites as a result of disease progression. Chest auscultation may reveal loud P2, S3 and S4. 

Investigations of PH include: 

  • Echocardiogram with bubble study - it is an important screening test. It usually shows a dilated, hypertrophied right ventricle and increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
  • Right heart catheterization - it is the gold standard test to establish the diagnosis of PH and to select appropriate therapy.
  • Chest X-ray - may show obliteration of retrosternal space, enlarged pulmonary arteries, and peripheral vascular pruning.
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

Other options: 

Option A: Acute STEMI would reveal ST elevations in ECG. It is an acute event while this patient has had insidious onset exertional chest pain. Pain is classically described as heavy, squeezing, and crushing. Cardiac biomarkers are also raised in STEMI.

Option C: Left-sided heart failure is characterized by pulmonary edema, dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Elevated JVP, weight gain, gastrointestinal symptoms and ascites are signs of right-sided heart failure. 

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of sudden death in young individuals. It is characterized by exertional dyspnea, angina, left-sided congestion, and left-ventricular outflow obstruction.

questions.text:
Match the following surgical procedures with the corresponding conditions for which they are performed:
Procedure Condition

1. Ramstedt's procedure

A. Peyronie's disease

2. Nesbitt procedure

 B. Biliary atresia

3. Heller's operation

 C. Infantile-hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

4. Kasai procedure

 D. Achalasia cardia
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B.

  1. Ramstedt's procedure - Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  2. Nesbitt procedure - Peyronie's disease
  3. Heller's operation - Achalasia cardia
  4. Kasai procedure - Biliary atresia

Ramstedt’s pyloromyotomy is performed by a laparoscopic or open supraumbilical incision for the treatment of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

Nesbitt procedure is the most commonly used procedure for treating Peyronie's disease. It corrects the deformity by plicating the convex side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Heller's Myotomy is done for achalasia cardia. It involves cutting the muscles of the lower esophagus and cardia of the stomach. It is often combined with a partial anterior fundoplication (Heller-Dor procedure) to avoid the complication of gastroesophageal reflux disease.

Kasai procedure (Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy) is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. In this procedure, radical excision of all bile duct tissues up to the liver capsule is performed. A Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with a continuous feeling of depressed mood that lasts most of the day. She has feelings of worthlessness, has no interest in doing anything and stays away from interacting with others. She has never experienced a manic episode and does not have any agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of a persistent depressed mood that lasts most of the day, with feelings of worthlessness, withdrawal from society, and loss of interest without psychomotor agitation, suicidal thoughts or any other medical history is suggestive of dysthymia.

Dysthymia is a persis­tent depressive disorder that is characterised by the presence of:

  • Insidious onset
    • Early: <21 years, more common
    • Late: > 21 years
  • Depressed mood that lasts most of the day, almost continuously.
  • Associated feelings of inadequacy, guilt, irritability, and anger
  • Withdrawal from society
  • Loss of interest, inactiv­ity, lack of productivity
  • Inertia, lethargy, and anhedonia are characteristi­cally worse in the morning

The disorder is more common in women and young people. It frequently coexists with other mental disorders, like major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder. 

The DSM-5 diagnosis criteria for dysthymia includes:

  • Presence of a depressed mood most of the time for at least 2 years (or 1 year for children and adolescents)
  • Presence of 2 or more features of poor appetite/overeating, insomnia/hypersomnia, low energy, low self-esteem, feelings of hopelessness or poor concentration.
  • Should not have symptoms that are part of major depressive disorder like disturbances in appetite and libido, psychomotor agitation or suicidal thoughts
  • Absence of any other medical illness or substance use that can cause this condition.
 

Treatment includes:

  1. Cognitive therapy
  2. Behaviour therapy
  3. Insight oriented psychoanalytic therapy
  4. Interpersonal therapy
  5. Family and group therapies
  6. Pharmacotherapy with SSRIs, venlafaxine and bupropion

Other options:

Option A: Double Depression is a condition with the presence of major depressive disorder along with dysthymia.

Option C: Cyclothymia is a chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance with many periods of hypomania and depression.

Option D: Patients with minor depressive disorder have a euthymic mood in between the episodes, but patients with dysthymia have virtually no euthymic periods.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female came with a history of jerky movements involving limbs and trunk. She also complains that she is more irritable nowadays. Her MRI from a previous doctor's visit shows marked atrophy of the caudate nucleus. The pedigree chart is given below and investigations show trinucleotide repeat (CAG) sequences. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage the movement disorder in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with trinucleotide repeat (CAG) sequences and the family pedigree showing the autosomal dominant mode of inheritance point towards a diagnosis of Huntington’s disease. VMAT2 (Vesicular monoamine transporter 2) inhibitor approved for the treatment of Huntington's chorea is deutetrabenazine.

Huntington's disease (HD) is a degenerative disease of the caudate and putamen (“striate neurons”) caused by an autosomal dominant inheritance of a trinucleotide repeat (CAG) in the Huntington gene (chromosome 4), which results in motor, behavioral, oculomotor, and cognitive dysfunction. HD is characterized by rapid, nonpatterned, semi-purposeful, involuntary choreiform movements of limb, face, or trunk. A phenomenon referred to as anticipation is seen particularly in males, with subsequent generations having larger numbers of repeats and earlier ages of disease onset.

Tetrabenazine and deutetrabenazine are inhibitors of VMAT2 and cause presynaptic depletion of catecholamines. Deutetrabenazine is a newer form of tetrabenazine approved for the treatment of chorea associated with Huntington's disease. Deutetrabenazine takes advantage of the stronger bonds that deuterium forms with carbon (deuterated tetrabenazine). They have a longer half-life than the corresponding products of tetrabenazine metabolism.

Tetrabenazine is extensively metabolized by CYP2D6. It may cause hypotension and depression with suicidal tendencies. It can also cause parkinsonism. Deutetrabenazine has adverse effects similar to those of tetrabenazine.

Other options:

Sodium valproate is used for moderate-severe Sydenham's chorea. It is characterized by involuntary, purposeless, jerky movements which mainly affect the head and upper limbs. In the tongue, it is visible as the characteristic darting movements.

Deflazacort: Corticosteroid approved for the treatment of Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy.

Edaravone: It is a free radical scavenger approved for the treatment of Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques cannot be employed for the household purification of water on a small scale?
questions.solution:
Chlorination is not suitable for household water purification on a small scale, as it is primarily designed for large-scale water purification.

Related Pearl: Purification of Water

Purification of water can be done on a large scale or small scale.

I) Purification of water on a large scale is done by one or more of the following measures:

a) Storage

b) Filtration

  • Slow sand filters
  • Rapid sand filters

c) Disinfection

  • Chlorination
  • Ozonation
  • UV radiation
  • Membrane processes like reverse osmosis, nanofiltration, ultrafiltration and microfiltration.

II) Purification of water on a small scale:

a) Household purification of water

  • Boiling
  • Chemical disinfection using bleaching powder, chlorine solution, high test hypochlorite, chlorine tablets, iodine and potassium permanganate.
  • Filtration using Pasteur Chamberland filter, Berkefeld filters or Katadyn filters
  • UV radiation
  • Multi-stage reverse osmosis

b) Disinfection of wells with bleaching powder

questions.text: A clinician asked the patient "how is your mood", the patient replied, "It goes up and down." What is this type of response known as?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is tangentiality. The patient has given a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly; it is tangential. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

 Tangentiality is a formal thought disorder.

Symptom Description
Circumstantiality Overinclusion of trivial or irrelevant details that impede the sense of getting to the point
Clang associations Thoughts are associated by the sound of words rather than by their meaning (e.g., through rhyming or assonance)

Derailment

(loose associations)

 A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.
Flight of ideas A succession of multiple associations so that thoughts seem to move abruptly from idea to idea; often (but not invariably) expressed through rapid, pressured speech.
Neologism The invention of new words or phrases or the use of conventional words in idiosyncratic ways.
Perseveration Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas.
Tangentiality In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic without actually answering the question
Thought blocking A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT
 

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."
 

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"
 
 

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT

(A) Obsession and compulsion

(i) Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

(ii) Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them
(B) Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud"
 

DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Derealization

Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal

  • "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

(vi) Depersonalization

Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body

  • "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

(vii) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)

 

DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

questions.text: All of the following are used to assess difficult airway except_____
questions.solution:
ASA classification is used to quantify patient risk for anesthesia and not difficult airway

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • History of snoring
  • Obesity
  • Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  • Previous head and neck radiation
  • Head and neck trauma
  • Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Down syndrome
  • Scleroderma
  • Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  • Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  • Thyromental distance <6.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  • Increased neck circumference (>17 inches in men or >16 inches in women)
  • Upper lip bite test : Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  • Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting a difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates an ease with intubation.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

questions.text: A young adult with a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome came to the outpatient department. All of the following are true regarding this condition except:

choices.text: Treatment diet should have low levels of fermentable oligosaccharides
ROME IV criteria is used to diagnose irritable bowel syndrome
Rifaximin is the antiobiotic approved for diarrhea-predominant IBS

questions.solution:
Significant elevation of faecal calprotectin is not true regarding irritable bowel syndrome. 

Assessment of faecal calprotectin levels helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. Hence, they are often assessed to distinguish the two conditions. These tests are also done to check if the disease is active and to detect postoperative recurrence. Other features of IBD include elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), hypoalbuminemia, anaemia, and leukocytosis.

IBS is a functional bowel disorder. It is characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of detectable structural abnormalities. Since there is no specific diagnostic marker for IBS, the diagnosis is based on Rome IV criteria which include the clinical manifestations of the disease. Abdominal pain is an anchor feature of IBS. It should be associated (improvement or worsening) with defecation, or with a change in the frequency or form of stool. Painless diarrhoea or constipation does not fulfil the criteria to be diagnosed as IBS. The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of IBS.

The extent of the diagnostic evaluation of a patient suspected to have IBS depends on the possibility of an organic disorder in that patient. A complete blood count and a sigmoidoscopy should be done for most patients. In addition, stool samples should be examined for ova and parasites in patients who have diarrhoea-predominant IBS.

The mainstay of treatment for IBS is a diet low in fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs).

Pharmacotherapy consists of Alosetron (5-HT3 antagonist) or Loperamide for diarrhoea-predominant IBS. The antibiotic that is specifically approved for diarrhoea-predominant IBS is rifaximin. It is an RNA synthesis inhibitor.  It may provide benefits by altering the gastrointestinal flora favourably.

Psyllium husk, lactulose, Lubiprostone, and Prucalopride (5-HT4 agonist) for constipation-predominant IBS. Peppermint oil is effective in improving abdominal pain associated with IBS, but probiotics have shown no benefit. 

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 23 yr old gravida 1, para 0 at 25 weeks gestation, presents with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. BP-104/72mm Hg, PR-72bpm. There is generalized edema. Peripheral smear shows hemolysis. Lab values are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Leukocyte count: 10,500/mm3
Platelet count: 62000/mm3
Hematocrit: 26%
AST: 90 IU/L
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is HELLP syndrome.

The typical presentation of right upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, lab findings of thrombocytopenia, low hematocrit, and peripheral smear finding of hemolysis, point towards a diagnosis of  HELLP ( Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelets) syndrome.

Although related to preeclampsia, hypertension and proteinuria may be absent or minimal in HELLP syndrome.

Tennessee criteria used in the diagnosis of HELLP syndrome :

  • Platelet count <1 lakh,
  • AST >70 IU/L,
  • LDH >600 IU/L

Risk factors for HELLP syndrome include

  • Preeclampsia
  • abnormal placentation
  • family history of HELLP syndrome
  • elevated levels of fetal mRNA for FLT l (vascular endothelial growth factor rfi­ receptor 1) and
  • Multiparity
  • Maternal age >34 years
  • European descent
  • History of previous poor pregnancy outcomes

Laboratory evaluation in HELLP:

  • Complete blood cell (CBC) count: Thrombocytopenia, anemia with possible reticulocytosis
  • Coagulation studies: Normal prothrombin time, 50% may have prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes, helmet cells, and burr cells secondary to microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase/alanine aminotransferase (AST/ALT) levels: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction
  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level: Elevated secondary to liver dysfunction or hemolysis
  • Elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN)/creatinine with acute renal failure
  • Bilirubin level: Increased secondary to hemolysis
  • Haptoglobin level: Decreased secondary to hemolysis
  • Fibrinogen levels: Low secondary to increased coagulation
  • D-dimer: Increased due to fibrinolysis/DIC

HELLP syndrome may lead to the development of DIC which manifests as increased fibrin split products and decreased fibrinogen levels.

questions.text: Identify the urinary crystal shown below:
questions.solution:
The given urinary crystal is the bipyramidal or envelope-shaped crystals of calcium oxalate dihydrate. Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones include higher urine calcium, urine oxalate, and lower urine citrate.

Oxalate-rich foods like spinach, rhubarb, almonds, and potatoes should be avoided. Avoiding high-dose vitamin C supplements reduces endogenous oxalate production.

Chlorthalidone can lower urine calcium excretion and can reduce the recurrence of calcium oxalate stones. Consumption of fruits and vegetables or supplemental alkali is advised to increase urine citrate, which is a natural inhibitor of calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones.

questions.text: The fluid of choice for resuscitation in the first 24 hours in a burns patient is ________.
questions.solution:
The fluid of choice for resuscitation in a burns patient is Ringer lactate in the first 24 hours followed by albumin and 5% dextrose.

This is in contrast to blunt and penetrating trauma patients in whom colloids (albumin, hydroxyethyl starch) hypertonic saline, and blood are preferred.

Recent Update: The initial fluid rate used for burns resuscitation has been updated by the American Burn Association to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula.

According to ATLS 10th edition,2018, the resuscitation formula used in thermal burns is 2 mL/kg × % TBSA.

First 8 hours: 1 mL/kg × % TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)
Next 16 hours: 1 mL/kg × %TBSA (lactated Ringer solution)

questions.text: Iritis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Iritis is seen in all the above conditions except rheumatoid arthritis.

Iritis or iridocyclitis is also known as anterior uveitis. 

Anterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis
  • Psoriasis
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Leprosy

Posterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Vogt-Koyanagi Harada syndrome
  • Diseases like toxoplasmosis, cysticercosis, coccidioidomycosis, toxocariasis, histoplasmosis
  • Infections- Candida, Pneumocystis carinii, Cryptococcus, Aspergillus, and Cytomegalovirus
  • Cat-scratch disease, Whipple’s disease, and brucellosis

Both anterior and posterior uveitis is seen in:

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Behcet's disease
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Herpes infections, Syphilis, Lyme disease, TB, onchocerciasis

Intermediate uveitis/pars planitis is seen in multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man underwent coronary artery bypass graft and has been in the hospital for the past 3 days. The patient is acutely confused with a temperature of 102°F and oxygen saturation of 91%. Blood test reveals raised inflammatory marker and chest X-ray shows a new right-sided infiltrate. Which of the following is the next best step in the diagnosis and/or management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform needle decompression and start antibiotics
Start treatment as per the local antibiotic policy for hospital acquired pneumonia after sending appropriate cultures
Perform  CT pulmonary angiogram to rule out pulmonary embolism
Immediately take the patient to theatre

questions.solution:
The clinical findings and radiological presentation are suggestive of pneumonia. Also, the patient has been in the hospital for > 2 days. The priority, in this case, is to start antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia after sending appropriate cultures.

Pneumonia is defined as the presence of new lung infiltrates along with clinical evidence of its infectious origin, which manifests with fever, purulent sputum, leucocytosis, and a decrease in oxygen saturation.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission.

  • Early-onset HAP (occurring within 4-5 days) is most commonly caused by S. aureus, P. aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, K pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli
  • Late-onset HAP (> 5 days) is usually caused by Gram-negative bacteria (ex: Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii), S. aureus, and anaerobes.

Management:

  • The mainstay of management includes adequate oxygenation, appropriate fluid balance and antibiotics. The choice of antibiotics is most appropriately guided by knowledge of local patterns of microbiology and antibiotic resistance.
  • Co-amoxiclav or cefuroxime are the preferred agents in early HAP. If the patient has recently received antibiotics, then piperacillin/tazobactam or a third-generation cephalosporin should be considered.
  • In late HAP, an anti-pseudomonal cover may be provided by meropenem, cephalosporin or piperacillin-tazobactam. MRSA cover may be given by glycopeptides such as vancomycin or linezolid. A baumannii is usually sensitive to carbapenem but may require colistin in resistant cases.

questions.text: A newborn child born to a mother with sickle cell disease is to be screened for sickle cell anaemia. Which of the following tests can be used?
questions.solution:
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is used for newborn screening of sickle cell anaemia and thalassemia.

Other options:

  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis is the confirmatory test for sickle cell anaemia and other hemoglobinopathies. e.g., thalassemia
  • Heel-prick Guthrie test is the neonatal screening test for phenylketonuria.
  • Tandem mass spectrometry is being used for neonatal screening of inherited metabolic disorders.

In India, a universal newborn screening program has been initiated only in some states which have high prevalence with plans to extend it to other areas.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of an itchy skin rash. On examination, there are multiple concentric rings with scaling, as shown in the image below. The patient reports intense itching, particularly within the rings, and mentions recent travel to Southeast Asia. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image show numerous concentric rings indicative of Tinea imbricata, resulting from infection by Trichophyton concentricum.

The lesion presents as a scaling ring; centrifugal spread follows, but within the area of central clearing a second wave of scaling soon arises. The process is repeated to give numerous concentric rings. Pruritus is intense and may lead to lichenification. Hypopigmentation may accompany the lesions. It is restricted to the natives of southern Asia, the islands of the South Pacific, Guatemala, southern Mexico, and Brazil.

Other options:

Option A: Trichophyton verrucosum: This dermatophyte fungus typically causes infections known as ringworm in cattle, often transmitted to humans upon direct contact with infected animals. It commonly affects farmers and individuals working in close proximity to livestock.

Option B: Microsporum ferrugineum: Microsporum species are known to cause various types of tinea infections, such as tinea capitis (scalp ringworm) and tinea corporis (body ringworm). 

Option D: Herpes Simplex virus: Herpes Simplex virus infections typically manifest as grouped vesicles or ulcers, often preceded by tingling or burning sensations.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child presents with episodes of vomiting after ingesting fruit juice. Which of the following enzyme deficiency is likely?
questions.solution:
Aldolase B deficiency is likely in this child.

In the given case scenario, the child becomes symptomatic after ingesting fruit juice which contains fructose; this indicates that he has hereditary fructose intolerance, which is caused by the deficiency of aldolase B.

Clinical features:

  • Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar).
  • Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It resembles galactosemia.
  • Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia.
  • Chronic intake results in failure to thrive and hepatic disease. Persistence of fructose intake can lead to liver failure, kidney failure, and death.

Treatment:

  • Complete elimination of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.
  • With age, symptoms become milder even after fructose ingestion. The long-term prognosis is good.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of new-onset left-sided chest pain. He had a recent history of a viral infection. ECG showed diffuse ST elevation with upward concavity and echocardiography detected a pericardial effusion. What is the finding that can be seen on the chest radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of pericardial effusion as a result of acute pericarditis. The chest radiograph may show a water-bottle configuration due to enlargement of the cardiac silhouette because of the pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion is usually associated with chest pain and/or the ECG changes of pericarditis (widespread ST elevation, often with upward concavity). If the effusion is large, the ECG may show electrical alternans. Heart sounds may be faint, friction rub, and the apical impulse may not be audible.

Echocardiography is a widely used imaging technique that allows localization and estimation of the quantity of pericardial fluid.

The chest X-ray shows an enlargement of the cardiac silhouette- water-bottle configuration. It may be normal in small effusions. The lateral radiograph may show the oreo cookie sign. It is a vertical opaque line (pericardial fluid) separating a vertical lucent line (paracardial fat) directly behind the sternum anteriorly from a similar lucent vertical line (epicardial fat) posteriorly. 

CT and MRI are indicated when echocardiography is inconclusive, when the effusion is loculated or hemorrhagic or if there is pericardial thickening.

Other options:

Option B: A Boot-shaped heart is seen in patients with Tetrology of Fallot. It refers to the appearance of an upturned cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy. 

Option C: Batwing appearance is seen in pulmonary edema. It refers to the appearance of perihilar consolidation.

Option D: The figure 3 sign is seen in the aortic coarctation. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and indentation of the left subclavian artery at the coarctation site and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.

questions.text: Two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old presents with ecchymosis and petechiae all over the body with no  hepatosplenomegaly. Platelet count = 15,000/microL and coagulation profile was normal. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy shows increased megakaryocytes
Bleeding into the joints is a common manifestation
The condition resolves spontaneously in 80% patients

questions.solution:
Mucocutaneous bleeding and reduced platelet count two weeks after an upper respiratory tract infection is suggestive of acute idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura. Bleeding into the joints is not a common manifestation of this condition.

Deep tissue bleeding (joints and muscles) such as muscle hematomas and hemarthrosis is seen in coagulation disorders or clotting factor deficiencies. 

Superficial mucocutaneous bleeding such as epistaxis, petechiae, ecchymosis is seen in bleeding disorders or platelet disorders.

Immune thrombocytopenic purpura or idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) is an acquired disorder in which there is an immune-mediated destruction of platelets.

Acute ITP:

  • Acute presentation with a self-limited course in children and resolves spontaneously in 80% patients.
  • Presenting features
    • Preceded by viral infection
    • Mucocutaneous bleeding
    • Hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, fever and jaundice are absent.
    • Resolves spontaneously in 80% of the cases in 4-6 weeks(Option D).
  • Laboratory features
    • Thrombocytopenia (commonly <20,000 / μL)
    • Normal/Increased megakaryocytes in bone marrow(Option B).
    • Prolonged bleeding time.
    • Normal tests for coagulation (PT/PTT/INR).
    • Peripheral smear is normal(Option A).

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in a case of ischemic stroke for all of these conditions, except _________.
questions.solution:
Thrombolysis is contraindicated in recent history of head injury.

Thrombolysis refers to the dissolution of the intravascular clots to prevent ischemic damage and improve blood flow. 

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (dose 0.9 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period within 4.5 hours of symptom onset.

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage

  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is thyroglossal cyst.

The above question describes a swelling which moves with deglutition. Classically, swellings associated with the thyroid move with deglutition. Goitre and thyroglossal cyst, move with deglutition. In this question, only thyroglossal cyst is given, so this is the answer.

The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. Thyroglossal cyst represents the persistence of the track of thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline.

Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion , and it indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. Although they often occur in children they may also present in adults, even as late as 6th or 7th decade.

Treatment:

Sistrunk’s operation

Excision of the whole thyroglossal tract , involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum together with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: Massive painless vaginal bleeding after a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea, in a premenopausal woman, is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Metropathia haemorrhaghica, a specialised form of anovulatory DUB, is seen in women aged 40 to 45 years.

Typical symptoms are continuous painless vaginal bleeding at the onset of menses, or preceeded by a 6-8 week period of amenorrhoea. Occasionally the woman gives a history of menorrhagia prior to this.

The uterus is slightly bulky, uniformly enlarged and the uterine wall shows a mild degree of myohyperplasia, measuring upto 2.5 cm. The endometrium is thick, polypoidal, and thin slender polyps project into the uterine cavity. The endometrium shows characteristic cystic glandular hyperplasia, which appears as a swiss cheese pattern.

The second feature is the absence of secretory endometrium i.e absence of cork screw glands (as the bleeding is anovulatory, there is no progesterone and hence no secretory changes in the endometrium).

Corpus luteum is absent and one or both ovaries may contain a cyst, not larger than 5 cm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, dizziness, and hyperventilation. His arterial blood gas analysis and serum electrolyte levels revealed metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap. Which of the following is the possible reason for this condition?
questions.solution:
Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap is a feature of renal tubular acidosis.

A renal tubular acidosis is a form of hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis which occurs when the renal damage primarily affects tubular function without much effect on glomerular function. The bicarbonate lost leading to acidosis is mirrored by an increase in chloride concentration and thus, the anion gap remains within normal limits. The result is a decrease in H+ excretion which is greater than that can be explained by any change in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR).

Entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is seen with lithotomy position, prone position and beach chair position.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation comes to the clinic. You do a bimanual examination with 2 fingers in the anterior fornix and fingers of other hands behind the uterus. The abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus. This is called :
questions.solution:
The scenario described in the question is the demonstration of Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: Bimanual examination with 2 fingers in anterior fornix and fingers of other hands behind the uterus, abdominal and vaginal fingers seem to appose below the body of the uterus which is due to softening of the isthmus. 

It is seen during pregnancy at 6-10 wks.

This sign is based on the fact that the upper part of the body of the uterus is enlarged by the growing fetus, the lower part of the body is empty and extremely soft and the cervix is comparatively firm.

Other options :

Option A - Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination, which is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C - Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D - Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Clinical Signs in Obstetrics

  • Chadwick’s Sign: Bluish hue to the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall. Seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. The cause is increased blood flow to the pelvic organs. Also known as Jacquemier’s Sign. /
  • Cullen Sign: Bluish discoloration of the skin around the umbilicus. Occurs due to intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Seen in ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Goodell Sign: Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state. Also due to increased blood flow
  • Hegar Sign: An indication of Pregnancy. The softening of the lower parts of the uterus enables the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers on bimanual pelvic examination.
  • Kustner’s Sign: Sign of placental separation. On pushing the uterus upwards does not move the cord with it due to the separation.
  • Ladin’s Sign: Softening in the midline of the uterus anteriorly at the junction of the uterus and cervix. It occurs at about 6 weeks gestation
  • Osiander’s Sign: Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity.
  • Palmer’s Sign: Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks. It is a sign of pregnancy
  • Piskacek’s Sign: Asymmetric growth occurs to the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts.
  • Schroeder’s Sign: A sign of placental separation. Uterus rises up when the separated placenta is passed downwards
  • Stallworthy’s Sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on the release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign. This sign is suggestive of posterior placenta praevia.
  • Turtle Sign: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.
  • Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign: Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus during early pregnancy. It occurs at 5-8 weeks gestation.

questions.text: What is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice for the metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor?
questions.solution:
Imatinib is the chemotherapeutic agent of choice for metastatic gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST).

Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. It has a dominant role in tumors involving ABL, KIT, or EGFR kinases. It is the chemotherapy agent of choice in the chronic phase of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) and metastatic GIST. 

Adverse effects:

  • Gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting
  • Fluid retention, edema, and periorbital swelling
  • Myelosuppression

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST) are mesenchymal tumors originating from the interstitial cells of Cajal, located in the gastrointestinal myenteric plexus. The most common mutation is the c-KIT mutation. GIST can also occur with SDH mutation and NF-1 mutation in neurofibromatosis-1.

GIST has specific tumor markers i.e., CD117 (c-KIT mutation) and DOG-1.

Succinyl dehydrogenase deficient (SDH) deficient GIST is commonly seen in Carney’s triad.

Carney’s triad:

  • Gastric GIST (succinyl dehydrogenase deficient)
  • Pulmonary chondroma
  • Extra adrenal paraganglioma

Other options:

Option A- Sunitinib is a multiple kinase inhibitor that is used in imatinib-resistant GIST and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.

Option C- Sorafenib is also a multiple kinase inhibitor that is used in the treatment of renal cancer and imatinib-resistant GIST. 

Option D- Dasatinib is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor and is used in imatinib-resistant CML.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever for the past 4 days and new onset of breathlessness was admitted to ICU as he was deteriorating. He was unresponsive to the incremental flow rate of oxygen and his oxygen saturation was progressively decreasing. A Chest X-ray was ordered and the findings are shown in the image below and his PaO2/FiO2 was 204 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of fever for less than 1 week, refractory hypoxia, chest x-ray showing bilateral infiltrates, and PaO2/FiO2 <300 mmHg is diagnostic of ARDS.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is characterized by rapid onset dyspnea, hypoxemia, and diffuse lung infiltrates resulting in respiratory failure. ARDS is caused by diffuse lung injury due to varied causes like inhalation injury, pneumonia, gastric aspiration, pulmonary contusion, burns, pancreatitis, and sepsis.

In patients with ARDS, there is an inflammatory response in the lungs leading to high levels of neutrophils and their secretory products in the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid. This is characteristic of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

An early chest x-ray typically reveals diffuse opacities due to consolidation. Later these opacities progress to more extensive and asymmetrical consolidation. The CT scan of the lungs shows heterogeneous involvement and predominantly affects gravity-dependent areas.

The affected airspaces are filled with fluid and cannot contribute to ventilation, leading to hypoxemia (due to increased pulmonary shunt) and hypercapnia (due to inadequate ventilation in some areas of the lung); resulting in, ventilation-perfusion mismatch.

The hypoxemia in ARDS is refractory to the increasing concentration of inhaled oxygen that occurs due to increased intrapulmonary shunting of blood.

The most common cause of death is sepsis in ARDS. Due to improvement in ventilator support systems, respiratory failure causes mortality in less than 20% of cases.

Diagnostic criteria in ARDS—Berlin definition: The Berlin definition requires each of the following criteria be present to diagnose ARDS:

  1. Onset- Acute: Respiratory symptoms must have begun within one week of a known clinical insult
  2. Bilateral alveolar or interstitial infiltrates: must be present on a chest X-ray image or CT scan
  3. Respiratory failure must not be fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload. Objective assessment e.g Echo should be done in cases of no known cause.
  4. Impairment of oxygenation must be present: The severity of hypoxemia defines the severity of ARDS

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a rash on the cheeks and nose, oral ulcers, and multiple joint pains. Investigations showed low serum complement levels. Antibody testing for which of the following is least likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The antibody test least likely to be positive in this scenario is the anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA). 

ANCAs are a group of autoantibodies involved in noninfectious vasculitis, such as microscopic polyangiitis, Churg-Strauss syndrome, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. They are useful diagnostic markers and can also be used to predict disease recurrence. The two most important ANCAs are anti-proteinase 3 and anti-myeloperoxidase.

SLE is an autoimmune disease that is seen more commonly in women. The abnormal immune response leads to the production of various forms of nucleic acids, proteins, and self-antigens. This, in turn, leads to the production of autoantibodies. In most cases, autoantibodies can be detected years before the start of clinical symptoms. The antibody deposition is then followed by complement-mediated destruction, resulting in tissue damage.

The most common rash seen in SLE is a slightly elevated, photosensitive rash seen around the cheeks and nose (butterfly rash). A few other clinical features include oral ulcers, non-scarring alopecia, and synovitis involving more than two joints. Some immunological features include ANA values more than reference negative values, the presence of Anti-Smith antibodies, low serum complement level, and positive direct Coombs test. 

The presence of at least four criteria with one from each category is a must for diagnosis of SLE, according to the 2012 Systemic Lupus International Collaborating Clinics (SLICC) classification system. 

Other options: 

Option A: The presence of anti-nuclear antibodies is the best screening test for SLE. It is seen in 98% of the cases. Repeated negative tests help to rule out the diagnosis. It has high sensitivity but poor specificity for SLE. 

Option B: Anti-ds DNA antibodies are seen in 70% of the cases. High titers are SLE specific. In a few patients, it indicates disease activity, nephritis, and vasculitis.

Option C: Anti-Smith antibodies are specific for SLE. It is seen more commonly in blacks and Asians than in whites.

In your paediatrics outpatient department, you see a boy of 8 years old who presented with jaundice and splenomegaly. Investigations were done and shown below. Further evaluation revealed an ankyrin gene mutation. Identify the false statement regarding the given condition from the following.

questions.solution:
The given clinical features of an 8-year-old boy with jaundice with hepatosplenomegaly and raised MCHC and ankyrin gene mutation are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. In this condition, only extravascular hemolysis is seen which occurs by macrophages in the liver and spleen.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anaemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant (Option A)pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2 and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. Patients usually present with anaemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The life span of affected red cells is decreased on average to 10 to 20 days from the normal 120 days.

In hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility of the red blood cells is characteristically increased. These spherocytes lyse more easily in a hypotonic solution than normal discoid RBCs due to the low surface area to volume ratio. There is increased osmotic fragility and hence the curve will shift towards the right. (Option C)

Patients usually present with anaemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually, the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

The peripheral smear shows numerous spherocytes which present as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor (Option B)that is present in normal red blood cells.

questions.text: The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all of the following except:

choices.text: Reduction in the risk of ovarian cancer
Protection against sexually transmitted diseases including HIV
Reduction in the risk of endometrial cancer

questions.solution:
The non-contraceptive uses of oral contraceptives include all except protection against sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including HIV.

Oral hormonal contraceptives can be combined oral contraceptive pills (COCPs) or progesterone-only minipills.

COCPs are a combination of ethinylestradiol at a dose of 20–30 mcg and an orally active progestogen. It is taken starting on the first day of the cycle for 21 days. They are taken at a fixed time of the day, preferably after a meal. Mala-N and Mala-D both contain levonorgestrel (0.15 mg) + ethinylestradiol (30 mcg). Mala-N is supplied free of cost in Family Planning Clinics in India. Each strip contains 21 hormonal tablets and 7 non-hormonal (iron) tablets. 

The mechanism of action is the prevention of ovulation by suppression of the pituitary hormones FSH and LH. Progesterone also acts on the cervical mucus, making it thick and impenetrable by sperm. The pregnancy rate with the COCP is 0.3 per 100 woman-years.

Benefits of the COCP:

  • It is effective in controlling fertility.
  • It causes regular cycles and reduces menstrual blood loss and are, therefore, useful in menorrhagia and polymenorrhea.
  • It lowers the incidence of benign breast neoplastic diseases, such as fibrocystic disease.
  • It reduces the incidence of functional ovarian cysts and ovarian (Option A) and endometrial malignancy (Option D). The incidence of ovarian cancer is reduced by 40% and that of uterine malignancy, by 50%, if taken for 1 year; this effect lasts as long as 10 years after stoppage.
  • It reduces the incidence of ectopic pregnancy (Option B) by suppressing ovulation and reducing the risk in pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • It is useful in endometriosis, acne, and polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD).

Side effects:

  • Higher incidence of breast cancer reported among users
  • Suppression of lactation
  • Occurrence of pituitary adenoma and adenoma of the liver
  • Reduced carbohydrate tolerance (therefore, contraindicated in diabetic women)
  • Migraine, depression, weight gain, and lethargy (due to progesterone)
  • Increased risk of pulmonary embolism and cerebral thrombosis

Ninety-nine percent of women will regain normal menstrual cycles within 6 months of stopping the pills, while the return of fertility is slightly delayed.

Barrier methods like condoms prevent the transmission of STDs.

questions.text: A patient complaining of pain in the right flank has been diagnosed with right-sided renal calculi measuring 2.2cm. Urine microscopy findings are shown in the image below. What is the most suitable treatment for this patient?

choices.text: No treatment required just pain management suffices

questions.solution:
The image of the urine microscopy shows hexagonal-shaped cystine stones. Hence the best suitable treatment for this patient with cysteine renal calculi measuring 2.2 cm is percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL).

Cysteine stone is relatively resistant to extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy and a stone size of more than 2 cm necessitates percutaneous nephrolithotomy. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy is done until the renal stone size of less than 1.5cm.

PCNL is indicated in the following condition:

  • If the patient has anatomical obstruction like pelviureteric junction obstruction, calyceal diverticula, or distal ureteral obstruction.
  • Hard renal stones like cystine stones, and calcium oxalate stones.
  • If the renal stone is struvite stone as it is associated with urinary tract infection.

Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the commonest method of treating urinary tract stones nowadays. Stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.

Complications of ESWL include infection, haematuria, parenchymal hemorrhage, and perirenal hematoma. ESWL is contraindicated in obese patients, pregnant patients, and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Note: Stone fragments collected in the distal ureter following ESWL are called steinstrasse.

    • Dihydrate: Octahedral or envelope shaped
  • Struvite stones: Rectangular or coffin lid

questions.text: Golden-S-sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Golden S-sign is seen on both PA chest radiographs and on CT scans in right upper lobe collapse. It is named because this sign resembles a reverse S shape, and is therefore sometimes referred to as the reverse S-sign of Golden. 

Although typically seen with right upper lobe collapse, the S-sign can also be seen with the collapse of other lobes. It is created by a central mass obstructing the upper lobe bronchus and should raise suspicion of a primary bronchogenic carcinoma. It can also be caused by other central masses, such as metastasis, primary mediastinal tumour, or enlarged lymph nodes.

The additional finding of this X ray is calcified breast implants.

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate presents with yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera. Which of the following may not be a cause of neonatal jaundice that appears after the first week of life?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis causes neonatal jaundice and manifests within the first 24 hours of life, not after 1st week.

Jaundice in the first 24 hours of life requires immediate attention and can be due to erythroblastosis fetalis, concealed hemorrhage, sepsis, or congenital infections, including syphilis, cytomegalovirus, rubella, and toxoplasmosis. Jaundice appearing on the 2nd or 3rd day of life is usually physiologic but also can be due to early onset breastfeeding jaundice and Crigler-Najjar syndrome (familial non-hemolytic icterus). Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 3rd day but within the 1st week of life can be due to bacterial sepsis, urinary tract infections or other infections like syphilis, etc.

Neonatal jaundice appearing after the 1st week of life can be due a number of conditions like breast milk jaundice, congenital atresia or paucity of bile ducts, hepatitis, cystic fibrosis, hemolytic anemia, enzyme deficiencies etc.

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is due to increased bilirubin production from the breakdown of fetal red blood cells combined with transient limitation in the conjugation of bilirubin by the immature neonatal liver. Continuation of breastfeeding exclusively resolves most of the cases.

questions.text: A grand multipara had continuous, moderate vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery. What could be the most probable cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum haemorrhage in a grand multipara.

Uterine atony is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery. Contraction helps to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site.

Types of PPH:

  1. Primary/early: Haemorrhage occurring within 24 hours of childbirth. Uterine atony is the most common cause of primary PPH.
  2. Secondary/late: Hemorrhage occurring after 24 hours and up to 12 weeks postpartum. Retained placenta is the most common cause.

The risk factors for atonic uterus include:

  1. Primiparity or grand multiparity
  2. Previous PPH
  3. Overdistended uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, macrosomia
  4. Precipitate labour
  5. Prolonged labour
  6. Uterine malformations
  7. Uterine fibroid
  8. Induction of labour with prostaglandins or oxytocin
  9. Placental abnormalities like placenta previa, accreta, increta, percreta, or abruptio placenta
  10. Obesity
  11. Age >40 years

Note: Uterine inversion occurs rarely and causes secondary PPH.

questions.text: In your internal medicine ward rounds,  you are reviewing a case of bilateral renal artery stenosis. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors must be avoided in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis (RAS).

In renal artery stenosis, blood flow to the kidney is reduced, thereby reducing blood flow to the afferent arterioles. Hence, constriction of efferent arterioles is needed to maintain hydrostatic pressure within the glomerulus in order to maintain GFR.

ACEIs and ARBs inhibit efferent renal arteriolar vasoconstriction. In bilateral RAS, this causes a decline in the GFR within a few days of starting the drug.

Note: Bilateral renal artery stenosis has been classically considered as an absolute contraindication to the use of ACE inhibitors. However, new studies show that they may be used in some cases with careful monitoring.

questions.text: A child of age 5 years presents with developmental delay and multiple seizure types. The seizures could not be controlled with multiple drugs. Electroencephalogram (EEG) shows 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves and polyspike bursts in sleep. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child having developmental delay, intractable seizures with electroencephalogram (EEG) showing 1-2 Hz spike, and polyspike bursts in sleep are all characteristic features of Lennox–Gastaut syndrome.

Lennox–Gastaut syndrome:

  • Typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years.
  • Consists of a triad of
    • Developmental delay
    • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
    • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness
  • Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

questions.text: A patient at 34 weeks of gestation is brought with decreased attention, clumsiness while walking, and headache since 12 hours. BP is found to be 190/110 mmHg. MRI of the brain shows areas of hypointensity on T1 flair in the occipital region. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient at 34 weeks of gestation now presents with altered sensorium and high blood pressure. The presence of hypointensities on T1 weighted MRIs in the occipital region makes posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome the likely diagnosis. 

PRES (Posterior Reversible Encephalopathy Syndrome)can occur with head injury, migraine, seizures, eclampsia and in the postpartum period. It is a hyperperfusion state with widespread segmental vasoconstriction and cerebral edema. Patients present with headaches and fluctuating neurologic signs and symptoms, especially visual symptoms.

MRI shows edema predominantly in the occipital lobes, seen as hypointensities on T1 flair. It can be generalized, but it is not confined to any single vascular territory. Ischaemia reverses completely.

Treatment is by slowly reducing the high blood pressure with IV drugs.

Other options: 

Option A: A Cerebrovascular accident can present with loss of function or weakness of limbs, signs of ataxia, or loss of sensory signaling based on the region affected due to ischemia or bleeding. However, this patient has no history of weakness, and the findings of the MRI make PRES more likely. 

Option C: Cerebral venous thrombosis presents with similar symptoms however, MRI will show a clot visible. Hypointensities in the posterior lobe is characteristic of PRES.

Option D: Subarachnoid hemorrhage can present with similar features but MRI will show a hyperintensity in the subarachnoid region on T1 flair

questions.text: A 3-day-old infant is brought with a rash. On examination, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions are noted, with no cardiovascular abnormality. CT head shows the following image. Which of the following is a true statement for the above-mentioned condition?

choices.text: Diffuse, scattered parenchymal calcifications is seen
Salt and pepper retinopathy is present
Pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine is the treatment of choice
Sensorineural hearing loss is a potential complication

questions.solution:
Sensorineural hearing loss is a potential complication is the true statement for the given condition. Based on the clinical findings of a child with chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions and with the CT image showing periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly, the most likely diagnosis in this infant is congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

CMV is the most common congenital infection. The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Diagnosis can be made by the presence of IgM antibodies in the fetal blood. Isolation of the virus from the urine or blood by PCR is more sensitive.

There is no definitive treatment for congenital CMV infection. Treatment with ganciclovir is indicated only in patients with progressive neurologic disease and deafness. Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

Other options:

Option A: Diffuse, scattered parenchymal calcifications are seen in congenital toxoplasmosis.

Option B: Salt and pepper retinopathy is seen in congenital rubella syndrome. It is due to the rubella virus. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome is deafness, cataract and congenital heart disease. Patent ductus arteriosus is a common cardiac defect. Eye findings also include salt and pepper retinopathy as shown below.

Option C: Pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine is the treatment of choice in congenital toxoplasmosis. It is due to Toxoplasma gondii. A classic triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracerebral calcifications is seen. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this. Calcifications occur randomly throughout the brain in congenital toxoplasmosis while periventricular calcification is characteristic of congenital CMV infection.

questions.text:
Match the following features with their corresponding syndromes

 

Features Syndrome
A. Pheochromocytomas, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, parathyroid hyperplasia 1. MEN 1
B. Parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, adrenal tumor, testicular tumor 2. MEN 2A

C. Mucosal neuromas, Marfanoid habitus, pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

 3. MEN 2B
D. Hyperparathyroidism, gastrinomas, prolactinomas  4. MEN 4
questions.solution:
The correct matched option is A-2, B-4, C-3, and D-1.

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia (MEN) refers to a group of inherited syndromes including various benign and malignant tumors of endocrine glands. There are four types - MEN 1-4. They have an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance and can also be sporadic. 

MEN 1 is a syndrome complex associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A comprises mainly medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B/3 consists of medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

questions.text: An elderly woman with hypothyroidism presents to the ER with decreased consciousness, sinus bradycardia, and hypotension. Her family members reveal that she has not been taking her thyroid medications recently. Investigations reveal elevated TSH levels and reduced T3 and T4 levels. Blood gases show hypercapnia, hyponatremia and hypoglycemia. Which of the following can be used in the treatment spectrum of this condition?

choices.text: Insulin bolus followed by IV fluids

questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests a case of hypothyroidism presenting in myxedema coma. Hypertonic saline is used in its treatment spectrum.

Myxedema coma refers to severe, life-threatening manifestations of hypothyroidism. It is mostly seen in the elderly. It is often precipitated by drugs (sedatives, antidepressants, anaesthetics), infections like pneumonia, congestive heart failure, myocardial ischemia, cerebrovascular accidents, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patients present with impaired consciousness, profound hypothermia (which can reach 23°C), hypoventilation, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia, hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and hypotension. It is associated with a high mortality rate.

Management of myxedema coma is with levothyroxine (T4) or liothyronine (T3). Levothyroxine is given intravenously, while liothyronine can be given via nasogastric or intravenous route. Parenteral hydrocortisone is used to correct the impaired levels of corticoid hormones. And the precipitating factors are treated symptomatically. Supportive therapy is by correcting the associated metabolic imbalance, external warming (if body temperature is <30 degrees) to prevent circulatory collapse by using space blankets, and ventilatory support if hypercapnia is present.

Other options:

Option A: IV diazepam is used in emergency management of status epilepticus. Hence, it is not used in the management spectrum of this condition.

Option B: Insulin bolus followed by IV fluids is not used since the patient already has hypoglycemia and there is no point in using insulin here in this state.

Option D: Stoppage of all steroid agents is not needed. But stoppage of known precipitating drugs can be stopped. On the other hand, parenteral steroids are used in the treatment of this condition.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with abdominal pain, proptosis, features of ataxia, and abnormal bursts of unusual eye movements as shown below. The child is found to have an intra-abdominal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis in this boy?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this boy is neuroblastoma. 

The clinical case shows a young child with abdominal pain, proptosis, ataxia, and abnormal eye movement. All these features point to a diagnosis of neuroblastoma, an intraabdominal tumour. 

Neuroblastoma is a malignant tumour seen in young children (<5 years). It is derived from neural crest cells of the adrenal medulla or the paravertebral sympathetic chain and is most commonly found in the abdomen. Most children have metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis.

The common clinical features are:

  • Intra-abdominal mass
  • Proptosis, periorbital bruising (raccoon eyes) 
  • Painless blue skin lesions (blueberry muffin syndrome)
  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome (rapid nystagmus + involuntary limb spasms)

The diagnosis can be made with a combination of biochemical tests (vanillylmandelic acid [VMA], homovanillic acid [HVA], dopamine, noradrenaline) and imaging studies (CT/MRI). This tumour often crosses the spine in the midline(different from Wilm's tumour which is mostly unilateral in nature).

Neuroblastoma:

  • Neuroblastoma is an embryonal tumour of the sympathetic nervous system. These tumours arise during fetal or early postnatal life from sympathetic cells derived from the neural crest. There­ fore, tumours can originate anywhere along the path which neural crest cells migrate, including:

    • Adrenal medulla
    • Paraspinal sympathetic ganglia
    • Sympathetic para­ ganglia such as the organ of Zuckerkandl.

    Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumour of childhood. While brain tumour is the most common solid tumour of childhood.

  • Neuroblastoma is a malignancy of neuroblast cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia and typically presents as an abdominal or paravertebral mass.
  • Raccoon eyes (periorbital ecchymoses) are seen in neuroblastoma due to orbital metastasis.
  • Blue subcutaneous nodules represent skin dissemination of tumour-associated with the "Blueberry Muffin Syndrome".
  • Shimada classification is used for classifying neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A patient is being considered for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). She takes some regular medications. Which of the following medications can be continued in this patient?
questions.solution:
Lithium, benzodiazepine, and bupropion should be discontinued before initiating electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). Tricyclic antidepressants can be continued during this period.

Before initiating electroconvulsive therapy, certain drugs that affect seizure induction, the seizure threshold or interact with drugs used during ECT should be withdrawn.

Lithium should be stopped because it can lead to postictal delirium and can prolong seizure activity. 

Benzodiazepines used for anxiety should be withdrawn because of their anticonvulsant activity.

Bupropion should be withdrawn because it is associated with late-appearing seizures.

Other drugs that are contraindicated for concomitant use include lidocaine and reserpine.

Tricyclic antidepressants, monoamine oxidase inhibitors and antipsychotics are generally considered acceptable for concomitant use.

Erythema gyratum repens presents as rapidly expanding erythematous, concentric rings resembling wood grain. Although it may signify an underlying malignancy, such as lung cancer, it is not typically associated with glucagonoma. Glucagonoma commonly presents with necrolytic migratory erythema.

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, pruritic skin rash characterized by grouped papules and vesicles. It is closely associated with celiac disease rather than lymphoma. Lymphoma may present with other dermatological manifestations, such as erythematous plaques or nodules.

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for a well-baby check-up. A lesion which was present since birth is noticed as given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots or dermal melanocytosis.

Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in colour or size.

Other options are also congenital dermatological presentations:

Option B: Salmon patch or naevus simplex is a small, pink-coloured ill-defined lesion that develops due to vascular ectasia.

Option C: Neonatal pustular melanosis is characterized by evanescent superficial pustules, ruptured pustules with fine scales, and hyperpigmented macules.
