questions.text: An 11-year-old child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever and having no valvular pathology comes to your clinic. What is the duration of prophylaxis given to this child?
questions.solution:
The duration of prophylaxis given to this child is 10 years.

The given scenario is a case of acute rheumatic fever without carditis and no valvular pathology. The secondary prophylaxis for this child is given for 5 years or till the age of 21, whichever is longer. Since the boy is 11 years old, prophylaxis for 10 years till the age of 21 years is longer than 5 years.

ARF is an autoimmune disease that develops in response to group A streptococcal infection. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 5-14 years. An upper respiratory tract infection with some M serotypes of the organism is the trigger. The concept of molecular mimicry is used to explain the pathogenesis of the condition. 

Since one attack of ARF increases the risk for further episodes and development of RHD, secondary prophylaxis is recommended by the American heart association (AHA) as follows:

  • Rheumatic fever without carditis: For 5 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer). 
  • Rheumatic fever with carditis but no residual valvular disease: For 10 years after the last attack or till 21 years of age (whichever is longer).
  • Rheumatic fever with persistent valvular disease, evident clinically or on echocardiography: For 10 years after the last attack or till the age of 40 (whichever is longer). Sometimes lifelong prophylaxis can be given.

Symptoms usually present after a latent period of about three weeks. Indolent carditis and chorea are the exceptions that can present even six months later. Migratory asymmetric polyarthritis which affects large joints and high-grade fever are common features. Cutaneous manifestations include erythema marginatum and subcutaneous nodules. Sydenham's chorea is commonly found in females and frequently affects the head and upper limbs. Acute rheumatic carditis can be seen as the involvement of the endocardium, myocardium, or pericardium. Histopathological examination shows Aschoff bodies and activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells.

The image below shows Aschoff bodies:

In chronic rheumatic heart disease, there is a leaflet and tendinous cord thickening along with commissural fusion and shortening of the mitral valve. Ultimately the valve can undergo stenotic changes giving it a fish-mouth appearance as shown below.

The modified Jones criteria is used for diagnosis. Management of ARF is mainly symptomatic by the use of antibiotics and NSAIDs.

questions.text: Identify the finding in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the foetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

If this part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os, the condition is called vasa previa. In this condition, rupture of the membranes leads to vaginal bleeding and foetal exsanguination.

Other options:

questions.text: The given pattern of EEG is found in:
questions.solution:
Periodic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes are seen in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).

It is a spongiform encephalopathy that is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar/visual disturbances. It is fatal and death usually within a year or less from the onset.

EEG shows characteristic periodic sharp wave complexes (bi/triphasic). CSF assay is positive for 14-3-3 protein.

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

  1. Sporadic (sCJD): Accounts for 85-90% of cases
    • MRI shows cortical ribbon sign
  2. Variant (vCJD): mad cow disease, Kuru
    • MRI shows hockey stick sign
  3. Familial (fCJD): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)
  4. Iatrogenic

Option A: Hepatic encephalopathy will show a triphasic wave pattern (negative-positive-negative wave). They are also seen in Hashimoto encephalopathy and CO2 narcosis.

Option C: GTCS (generalized tonic clonic seizures)will show high voltage bursts & high voltage spikes present in all the leads.

Option D: HSV encephalitis usually affects one side temporal lobe showing a characteristic periodic lateralised epiletptiform discharge.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea. Laboratory investigations reveal decreased estrogen, FSH, and LH. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Decreased levels of estrogen, FSH, and LH are suggestive of hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism, which is caused by Kallman syndrome.

It is an X-linked disorder (KAL gene) that causes isolated hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism and anosmia.

Causes of hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism:

  • Congenital
    • Kallman's syndrome 
    • Isolated hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism (IHH)
    • Prader-Willi syndrome
    • CHARGE syndrome
  • Acquired
    • Pituitary tumors, apoplexy
    • Hyperprolactinemia
    • Anorexia nervosa, excess exercise
    • Irradiation
    • Infection
    • Trauma

Option A: Asherman syndrome causes secondary amenorrhea due to intrauterine synechiae.

Option B: Müllerian agenesis presents with primary amenorrhea with normal levels of all hormones.

Option D: Turner's syndrome causes primary amenorrhea due to hypergonadotrophic hypogonadism.

questions.text: A young male patient is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
The given history of long-standing suspiciousness, not trusting people, and bearing grudges for insults is suggestive of paranoid personality disorder.

Paranoid personality disorder, a part of cluster A personality disorders, is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful of perceived threats and deceit and often read hidden demeaning or threatening meanings into benign remarks. They are reluctant to confide in others due to the fear that the information they provide will be used against them maliciously.

They tend to be extremely jealous, hostile, argumentative, and defensive. Their paranoia prevents them from establishing any overly-involved relationship. They persistently bear grudges and can get irritable and angry easily. They use the defense mechanism of projection by displacing their insecurities on others. 

They may not be willing to accept that they need psychiatric help. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice. Care should be taken by the therapist to not behave defensively if accused of making a mistake. Pharmacotherapy is generally used to deal with anxiety and agitation. Diazepam is used as an anxiolytic while antipsychotics like haloperidol or pimozide may be required to deal with agitation.

Other options:

Option A: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are usually eccentric and isolated. They neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They always choose to be alone and lack close friends. They are emotionally cold and appear indifferent to praise or criticism.

Option B: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder appear odd and strange to surrounding people. They have ideas of reference, odd or magical thinking, inappropriate or constricted affect, and suspiciousness.

Option D: Individuals with histrionic personality disorder have excessive emotional and attention-seeking behavior. They are uncomfortable in situations where they are not the center of attraction. They also have inappropriate sexually seductive or provocative behavior. They try to use their physical appearance to draw others' attention.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the emergency department with severe fatigue and prostration. She is a known case of chronic stable angina. While collecting a blood sample, you notice the blood has a brownish hue. What is the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with chronic stable angina, presenting with fatigue and brownish-colored blood is suggestive of methemoglobinemia. For the management of chronic stable angina, she must be taking nitrates and methemoglobinemia is a rare complication of nitrate (isosorbide) consumption.

Nitrate ions released during the metabolism of isosorbide oxidize hemoglobin (Fe2+) to the brown methemoglobin (Fe3+), thereby producing methemoglobinemia. The risk of developing clinically significant methemoglobinemia is higher in patients with coronary ischemia and anemia.

Interestingly, pulse oximetry in methemoglobinemia shows a plateau of 80% to 85% irrespective of the arterial oxygen saturation and irrespective of the methemoglobin levels. Co-oximeters that can differentiate methemoglobin from carboxyhemoglobin, oxyhemoglobin, and deoxyhemoglobin are thus preferred for the diagnosis of methemoglobinemia.

Treatment of methemoglobinemia associated with isosorbide toxicity involves supportive care, cessation of isosorbide consumption, and reduction of methemoglobin to hemoglobin by intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg).

Other options: 

Option A: Carboxy-hemoglobinemia occurs due to acute and chronic carbon monoxide intoxication through occupational exposure and exposure to incompletely burned hydrocarbons. It presents with headache, altered mental status, and other constitutional symptoms.

Option B: Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia that occurs in the presence of normal to high levels of iron. The characteristic ring sideroblasts are seen in the peripheral smear. Causes of sideroblastic anemia include pyridoxine deficiency, lead poisoning, and alcoholism.

Option D: Sulfhemoglobinemia is a rare irreversible condition that can occur with the ingestion of drugs such as dapsone and sulphonamides.

questions.text:
A chest X-ray of a patient with a productive cough and evening rise in temperature for 3 weeks duration is done and it shows cavities in the upper lobe. The clinician suspects pulmonary TB and orders a sputum smear examination on two samples which turn out to be negative. He further advises CB-NAAT which reveals the presence of Mycobacterium but is indeterminate on Rifampicin resistance. What should be done next as per the recent NTEP guidelines?

CB-NAAT - Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification

choices.text: Start treatment as drug sensitive TB and continue Intensive phase for 3 months
Repeat CB-NAAT testing to ascertain drug resistance before initiating treatment
Consider taking fresh sample and test it using line probe assay to detect resistance
Start treatment with MDR TB regimen using oral drugs only for 18 months

questions.solution:
As per the NTEP guidelines, repeat CB-NAAT testing to ascertain drug resistance, needs to be carried out if the first sample tested is Rif indeterminate/inconclusive.

The given case with the typical symptoms of evening rise of temperature and productive cough of more than 2 weeks duration with chest x-ray showing upper lobe cavities prompts a diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis. The initial diagnosis of pulmonary TB is done with sputum smear examination and chest radiography. In this case, despite 2 negative sputum samples, a chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Hence CB-NAAT was performed. 

In cases of high clinical suspicion, Smear is negative but CXR findings are suggestive, or in people with HIV, a CB-NAAT is done. Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification (CBNAAT) detects the presence of Mycobacterium DNA along with resistance against Rifampicin within 2 hours. It analyses sputum or any other biological specimen (except blood and blood-contaminated specimens) using real-time PCR technology

If Rifampicin resistance is absent, it is treated as drug-sensitive TB. If Rifampicin resistance is present, it is treated as drug-resistant TB. 

However, if the sample turns out to be intermediate/inconclusive, CB-NAAT is repeated using 2nd sample.

  • If the 2nd sample turns out to be positive for Rifampicin resistance, the patient is treated as Rifampicin resistant
  • If the 2nd sample turns out to be negative for Rifampicin resistance, the patient is treated as drug-sensitive
  • If the 2nd sample also turns out to be indeterminate, a fresh sample is taken for Line probe assay or liquid culture, to ascertain drug resistance.

A positive smear examination irrespective of CXR findings is diagnosed as microbiologically confirmed TB and started on ATT. Drug sensitivity is done for all new cases due to increasing resistance. Once these drug sensitivity results are available, treatment can be modified, if resistance is found.

questions.text: All of the following drugs can be eliminated by the forced alkaline diuresis method except?
questions.solution:
Atropine is eliminated by forced acid diuresis while the other drugs given can be eliminated by forced alkaline diuresis.

Forced diuresis means increasing urine formation by administering diuretics and fluid to the patients. This may increase the excretion of certain drugs in urine and is used to treat drug overdose or poisoning of these drugs. Most diuretic drugs are either weak acids or weak bases. When urine is made alkaline, the elimination of acidic drugs in the urine is increased. When urine is made acidic converse alkaline drugs are eliminated. It is of two types as follows:

Forced alkaline diuresis is useful in weak acids. Here, sodium bicarbonate is used to turn the urine alkaline. It achieves a urinary pH of 7.5 to 9 and promotes the excretion of drugs that are weak acids such as salicylates, phenobarbital, chlorpropamide, methotrexate etc.

Forced acid diuresis is useful for weak bases. Here, ammonium chloride is used to turn the urine acidic. It is useful in treating poisoning with atropine, amphetamine, chloroquine, cocaine, quinine, and tricyclic antidepressants.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presented to the hospital with gangrene of the 4th and 5th digits of the right hand.  He also complains of pain in the upper and lower limb. On examination, his BP was 160/100 mmHg and his peripheral pulses were palpable. ANCA was negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. The presence of myalgia, the involvement of the cutaneous vessels (gangrene with palpable peripheral pulses), and renal vessels causing hypertension and serology negative for ANCA suggest the diagnosis.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, mesenteric vessels (including renal), heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN.

The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, the patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings of the polyarteritis nodosa include skin ulcers, digital gangrene, and livedo reticularis.
  • The involvement of renal arteries leads to hypertension and renal failure.
  • The involvement of mesenteric arteries may lead to abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and bowel perforation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with chronic itchy plaques over the neck and bilaterally over the popliteal and cubital fossae. His mother reports that the itching is aggravated by sweating. What is the location of the defective structural protein responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of chronic itchy plaques over the neck and bilaterally over the popliteal and cubital fossae suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis. This condition is secondary to the mutation of the filaggrin protein which is seen in the outermost layer of the epidermis called the stratum corneum, depicted by A in the image.

Filaggrin protein is responsible for keratin filament aggregation and the production of natural moisturizing factors. Filaggrin protein

The normal epidermis is composed of differentiated, stratified squamous epithelium. Keratinocytes are the majority of the cells, which move progressively from attachment to the epidermal basement membrane towards the skin surface. From superficial to deep, the layers of the epidermis are marked in the below image:

Atopic dermatitis is the cutaneous expression of the atopic state, characterized by a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or eczema. The epidermal barrier is impaired due to a mutation in the gene encoding filaggrin (a structural protein in the stratum corneum).

In infants, it presents as erythema and edematous papule in the face and extensor aspect of the knees and elbows. The papules are intensely itchy and may become exudative and crusted as a result of rubbing.

The site of lesions shifts to elbow and knee flexures when the child is 18 months to 2 years. There is also a mixture of erythema, crusting, excoriation, hyper- and hypopigmentation, and warty lichenification seen on the sides of the neck, wrists, and ankles. Blanching of the skin occurring at the site of stroking or scratching, which is called white dermatographism, is also seen.

Other features of atopic dermatitis include xerosis (dry skin), ichthyosis (fish-like scaly skin), and headlight sign (facial eczema sparing periorbital, perinasal, and perioral area).

questions.text: A young woman came to the gynaecologist with complaints of inability to conceive even after regular intercourse. Semen's analysis of her partner was unremarkable. Hysterosalpingography revealed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the hysterosalpingogram are indicative of a unicornuate uterus.

The history of infertility and hysterosalpingography(HSG) showing a spindle-shaped or banana-shaped uterine cavity deviated to the left with a patent left fallopian tube suggests a unicornuate uterus. It results from the failure of the normal development of one müllerian duct.  It is associated with increased spontaneous abortion, obstetric complications, and renal abnormalities.

On T2-weighted MR images, the unicornuate uterus demonstrates a curved, elongated uterus with tapering of the fundal segment off the midline. This is known as the banana-like configuration. Normal uterine zonal anatomy is maintained.

If a functional rudimentary horn is present, it usually demonstrates lower signal intensity and might contain endometrial tissue. They have increased chances of endometriosis and hematometra which can be an indication for excision.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with painful swelling of the right calf muscle, 7 days after her knee replacement surgery. On examination, her heart rate is 70 beats per min, her blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and her SpO2 is 96% on room air. Homan's test is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of deep venous thrombosis(DVT).

Deep vein thrombosis:

Causes

  • Postoperative thrombosis: (Most common cause)
    • Following childbirth
    • Trauma- to leg, ankle, thigh, pelvis
    • Immobility – Bed-ridden patients, individuals on long-duration air or bus travel (Traveller’s thrombosis).
    • Debilitating illness, obesity, immobility, bed rest, pregnancy, puerperium, oral contraceptives, estrogens.

Sites

  1. Pelvic veins—common
  2. Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (Common on the left side).

Features of DVT

  • Fever-commonest
  • Tense, tender, warm, pale/bluish, shiny swelling calf
  • Positive Homan’s, Mose’s sign
  • Inverted beer bottle sign/ champagne bottle sign
  • Commonly it is asymptomatic
  • Features of pulmonary embolism

Note:

Mose's sign- Squeezing of the relaxed calf muscles from side-to-side is also painful as the thrombosed deep veins in the calf are always tender and this test is known as Moses’ sign.

Homans sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below. 

Treatment

  • Rest, the elevation of the limb, bandaging the entire limb with crepe bandage.
  • Anticoagulants: Heparin/low molecular weight heparin, warfarin, phenindione.
  • Palma operation
  • May-Husni operation

Pulmonary embolism is the commonest complication of deep vein thrombosis leading to death.

  • Age
  • Obesity
  • Varicose veins
  • Immobility
  • Pregnancy
  • Puerperium
  • High-dose estrogen therapy
  • Previous deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

Thrombophilia

    • Deficiency of antithrombin III, protein C or protein S
    • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant
    • Factor V leiden gene defect or activated protein C resistance
    • Dysfibrinogenaemias
  • Acquired

  • Malignancy, especially pelvic, and abdominal metastatic
  • Heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Paralysis of lower limb(s) infection
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Polycythaemia
  • Paraproteinaemia
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
  • Behçet’s disease
  • Homocysteinemia

questions.text: During a pre-operative consultation, a 32-year-old female patient expresses concerns about the type of anaesthesia for her upcoming surgery. She specifically asks about the differences between epidural and spinal anaesthesia. Which of the following is not true about epidural anaesthesia, in comparison to spinal anaesthesia?

choices.text: The density of the block is less
Less chances of post-dural puncture headache

questions.solution:
Epidural anaesthesia has a slower onset of action, as compared to spinal anaesthesia.

Epidural anaesthesia is a method of neuraxial pain control in which anaesthetic medications are injected into the epidural space to block sensory and motor spinal nerve roots in the thoracic, abdominal, pelvic, and lower extremity areas. 

Epidural techniques are widely used for surgical anaesthesia, obstetric analgesia, postoperative pain control (Option D), and chronic pain management.

In epidural anaesthesia, the needle does not penetrate the dura mater; hence, the chances of a post-dural puncture headache are low. (Option C) However, compared to spinal anesthesia, it has a slower onset of action and a low density (Option B) of the block. 

The image below is of the 18G Tuohy needle, which is the most common needle used in epidural anaesthesia.

 

The needle shaft is calibrated and has a blunt, curved tip (Huber tip) that prevents accidental dural puncture. It is made from a flexible, radio-opaque plastic so that the depth of insertion can be identified.

questions.text: A 1 year-old boy was undergoing treatment for  CTEV with POP cast for the last 6 months. However his deformities didn't improve.  What is the next best step in this case?
questions.solution:
The next best step in this case is posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) also known as Turco's procedure.

By 1 year of age, posteromedial soft tissue gets contracted leading to difficulty in manipulation of joint. Hence, in PMSTR tight soft tissue structures (tendons, ligaments, capsule) on the posterior and medial side of the foot are removed.

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: Which of the following is the IOC to detect abnormally located placenta?

Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is the investigation of choice and is superior to Transabdominal sonography (TAS) for detecting placental abnormalities.

questions.text: A Patient with prostrate cancer receives sequential radiotherapy at a dose of 1.8-2.4 Gy for 5 days every week, for 5-7 weeks this is called as ?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy at a dose of 1.8-2.4 Gy for 5 days per week, over 5-7 weeks is called as Regular Fractionated Radiotherapy

The conventional schedule for radiotherapy involves the delivery of 70 Gy in 2 Gy fractions over 7 weeks, treating 5 days per week.

Shorter schedules remain useful for small-volume treatments: 50 Gy in 16 fractions over 3 weeks or 55 Gy in 20 fractions over 4 weeks.

Accelerated schedules although is easier to implement than hyperfractionation result in a lesser survival gain.

questions.text: Which of the following curve corresponds to brain growth?
questions.solution:
The curve corresponding to brain growth is B

Brain growth occurs during the later part of fetal life and first two years after birth. The head is around 65-70% of adult size at birth and reaches 90% by the age of 2 years. 

Other options:

Option A: Lymphoid growth is prominent in the mid-childhood. It peaks at 4–8 years when the lymphoid tissue overgrows and may appear to be larger than that adult. This can be evident in the form of enlarged tonsils and palpable lymph nodes that regresses and subsequently reach adult size.

Option C: General body growth shows an S-shaped curve. It is rapid during the fetal period and the first 3–4 years. It is steady in the following period, followed by a growth spurt during puberty. Later, it slows down considerably.

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia, and left Horner’s syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
These given features collectively indicate a diagnosis of Wallenberg or lateral medullary syndrome, which is typically caused by a lesion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. 

The patient presents with hoarseness and dysphagia, suggesting the involvement of cranial nerves IX and X, which helps localize the lesion to the medulla. Additionally, the presence of vertigo and diplopia (involving the vestibular nerve), left-sided Horner's syndrome (involving the descending sympathetic tract), numbness on the left side of the face (involving the sensory tract of trigeminal nucleus), and numbness in the right side limbs (involving the lateral spinothalamic tract) further aids in localizing the lesion to the lateral part of the medulla.

The absence of motor symptoms suggests that the pyramidal tracts in the medial aspect of the medulla are not involved, ruling out medial medullary syndrome.

Wallenberg/lateral medullary syndrome affects:

  • Descending tract and nucleus of CN V- loss of pain and sensation over the ipsilateral half of the face.
  • Inferior cerebellar peduncle – ipsilateral ataxia 
  • Lateral spinothalamic tract – loss of pain and temperature sensation over the contralateral half of the body. 
  • CN IX and X - ipsilateral paralysis of palate, vocal cord, diminished gag reflex giving rise to dysphagia, dysarthria.
  • Vestibular nucleus - Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, nausea
  • Descending sympathetic tract – ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis).

questions.text: Which of the following devices causes the least amount of collateral tissue damage when used?
questions.solution:
The harmonic scalpel is associated with the least amount of collateral tissue damage as compared to the other devices.

It is an instrument that uses ultrasonic energy to simultaneously cut and coagulate tissues. The scalpel vibrates at a frequency of 20000-50000 Hz and cuts through tissues, achieving hemostasis by sealing vessels and tissues through protein denaturation using vibration rather than heat.

Several surgical procedures have been made easier by this nonelectric technique for coagulating and dividing tissue with minimal energy transfer to the surrounding tissues. It is especially useful in the control of bleeding from medium-sized vessels that are too big to manage with monopolar electrocautery. 

Currently, it is used for laparoscopic procedures, as well as open surgery, such as thyroidectomy, and several plastic surgery operations, e.g. cosmetic breast surgery. It provides cutting precision even through thickened scar tissue, and visibility is improved because this system produces less smoke during use than standard electrosurgery.

Other options:

Option B and D: Electrocautery in both coagulation and cutting modes causes lateral thermal spread, resulting in collateral tissue damage. However, the coagulation mode generates less heat at a slower frequency, with the potential for large lateral thermal spread, whereas the cutting mode generates a lot of heat quickly over the target, with comparatively less lateral thermal spread.

Option C: Argon beam coagulator is a specialized form of radiofrequency electrocautery, which delivers electrical energy through an arc of ionized (argon) gas. This high­flow argon gas conducts electrical current to the target tissue and generates thermal coagulation of this tissue. It can cause thermal penetration to a maximum depth of 6mm which can spread to surrounding tissue as well.

This technology is most useful for coagulating diffusely bleeding surfaces, such as the cut edge of the liver or spleen. It is less useful in laparoscopic procedures because the increased intra-abdominal pressures caused by the argon gas jet can increase the chances of a gas embolus.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis and HIV was started on both anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) and antiretroviral therapy (ART). After 2 months, the patient experienced a deterioration in his health. What is the most likely cause?

choices.text: Drug-drug interaction between TB and HIV medications
Development of drug resistance to anti-tubercular drugs
Development of drug resistance to ART

questions.solution:
In a patient diagnosed with TB and HIV who was started on ATT and ART, the deterioration in health after treatment initiation point to a diagnosis of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) due to immunological changes in the body.

Following the initiation of effective anti-retroviral therapy, a paradoxical worsening of preexisting or untreated opportunistic infections may be seen in people living with HIV (PLHIV). This is known as immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). IRIS is seen in up to 30% of the patients who are started on ART, and is particularly common in patients with untreated mycobacterial or fungal infections, or with CD4+ T-cell counts <50 cells/μL. Other risk factors for the development of IRIS include:

  • Rapid initial fall in HIV viral load due to ART
  • Severity of TB disease
  • Male sex and younger age

The underlying pathogenesis appears to be similar to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction and reflects the immediate improvements in immune function as there is a drop in the levels of HIV RNA. IRIS related to a known pre-existing infection is called paradoxical IRIS; IRIS associated with a previously undiagnosed condition is referred to as unmasking IRIS. Signs and symptoms can appear within two weeks to two years of starting ART and can include lymphadenitis, prolonged fever, pulmonary infiltrates, hepatitis and increased intracranial pressure.

IRIS is generally self-limiting and interruption of ART is rarely indicated. In most cases, recognition and management of ongoing infection with antimicrobial therapy is sufficient. Short-term therapy with corticosteroids or NSAIDs can be given to reduce the inflammation. Temporary cessation of ART is to be considered for potentially life-threatening forms of IRIS. For the prevention of IRIS in a patient with HIV and TB co-infection, anti-tubercular treatment is started first and then ART is added two weeks later.

questions.text: A case of carcinoid syndrome was evaluated and identify the most commonly involved heart valve in this case.
questions.solution:
The most commonly involved value in carcinoid syndrome is the tricuspid valve.

The right heart is more commonly affected than the left heart, with tricuspid involvement in more than 97% of patients. This is likely due to the effects of bradykinin and serotonin coming in contact with the tricuspid valve first. The pulmonary capillary bed degrades the metabolites and serves as a filter, relatively protecting the left side of the heart from fibrosis. (Options B, C, D)

Carcinoid heart disease is characterized by the formation of fibrous plaques on the heart valves, chambers, and blood vessels. These plaques can distort the valves, leading to stenosis or regurgitation. Patients with obvious carcinoid symptoms, such as flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm, are more likely to have cardiac involvement. Physical examination may reveal a murmur and signs of right heart failure. 

The carcinoid tumours are neuroendocrine tumours arising from enterochromaffin cells that can occur anywhere in the GIT. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum. a tumour with metastasis to the liver is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. 

The diagnosis is made by an assessment of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumours only if metastases are present.  

Ultrasonography, CT scan, and MRI may show the primary tumour and metastases. The best method for staging carcinoid tumours is by octreotide scan or somatostatin receptor scintigraphy (SRS).

Treatment:

Somatostatin and its analogues are used in the symptomatic treatment of carcinoid syndrome. 
Surgery should be undertaken as soon as the diagnosis is made, even in the presence of liver metastases.

The most common small intestine tumour is carcinoid.
The most common site of small intestine carcinoid is the ileum.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Treatment involves hysteroscopic lysis of the adhesions

questions.text: A female patient has dysphagia, with  intermittent epigastric pain. On endoscopy, the esophagus was found to be dilated above and narrow at the bottom. Treatment is _______
questions.solution:

 Non-surgical:

    • tortuous esophagus (megaesophagus)
    • sigmoid esophagus
    • failure of more than one myotomy

  • Peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) is a recently introduced, advanced natural-orifice approach for myotomy.
  • The addition of a partial antireflux procedure, such as a Toupet or Dor fundoplication, will restore a barrier to the reflux and decrease the severity of postoperative symptoms.
  • Modified laparoscopic Heller myotomy is the operation of choice.
  • Advantage: Definite treatment of end-stage achalasia patient
  • Eliminates the risk of carcinoma in the resected area
  • Approaches: Transthoracic/Transhiatal

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you least expect to observe while evaluating a case of Conn's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The findings least expected to observe while evaluating a case of Conn's syndrome are low aldosterone: renin ratio.

Patients with Conn's syndrome exhibit primary hyperaldosteronism, characterised by low serum renin levels and an elevated aldosterone: renin ratio.

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. The increase in aldosterone results in a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually less than 4-6 mEq/L over the normal range, hypokalemia (due to increased K+ excretion), hypertension (due to slight increase in ECF volume), metabolic alkalosis because increased hydrogen ions are secreted in the urine.

When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn's syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with severe generalized body ache, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and low mood for the past 4 months. Increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences are noted on examination. Laboratory and radiological investigations show normal results. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness accompanied by other non-specific somatic symptoms like fatigue and sleep disturbance, for more than three months. 

It is more common in females. On examination, they have tenderness in multiple soft tissue anatomical locations. Laboratory findings are unremarkable. 

Patients with fibromyalgia may have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes.

Other options-

Options A & B- Polymyositis and systemic lupus erythematosus have positive laboratory findings such as specific antibodies and radiological findings of multiorgan involvement, for example, interstitial lung disease in polymyositis.

Option C- Although the given clinical scenario closely resembles clinical depression, the examination findings showing tenderness and pain sensitivity favor the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

  • Non-pruritic, morbilliform rash, which appears as the fever comes down.
  • Leucopenia and relative lymphocytosis
  • Nagayama spots: ulcers at uvulo-palatoglossal junction

Diagnosis includes polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for detecting the viral DNA.

This is a self-limiting disease and treatment is done as supportive care in the form of maintaining hydration and using antipyretics if the child has a fever.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman experiences increased frequency of micturition, pain relieved by micturition, and aggravated by overdistension of the bladder. questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks of gestation presents to the OG clinic for targeted sonography.  In the sonogram, a finding of a single umbilical artery is noted.  Which of the following is true regarding the finding?

choices.text: An indicator of increased risk of malformations of the fetus
Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers

questions.solution:
Single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It is an indicator of increased incidence of congenital malformations in the fetus.  

It is more common in twins and in babies born of women with diabetes, epilepsy, oligohydramnios, hydramnios, pre-eclampsia, and antepartum hemorrhage.

It is frequently associated with congenital malformation of the fetus (20–25%), mainly cardiovascular and genitourinary. Renal and genital anomalies, trisomy 18 are common.

There is an increased chance of abortion, fetal aneuploidy, prematurity, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and increased perinatal mortality.

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching without vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely related to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen is suggestive of gastric volvulus. Most likely related to gastric volvulus is the Borchardt's triad.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

The Borchardt triad comprises of:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Radiograph images shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B- Dieulafoy’s triad is seen in acute appendicitis. It comprises of hypersensitiveness of skin, reflex muscular contraction, tenderness at Mc Burney’s point.

Option C- Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option D- Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with symptoms of food impaction, dysphagia, and a burning sensation in his chest. Based on the barium swallow image given below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium swallow image showing the feline esophagus sign are suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis.

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an idiopathic condition commonly affecting the proximal 1/3rd of the esophagus. Eosinophils migrate to the esophagus and contribute to extensive tissue damage and inflammation.  

Clinical features include difficulty in swallowing, food impaction, vomiting, heartburn, and symptoms similar to those of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Non-responsiveness to proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy is often seen. 

Barium swallow shows the presence of a series of rings in the esophagus. These rings appear similar to stripes on a cat, and the appearance is referred to as the feline esophagus sign. It is thought to be due to contraction of the muscularis mucosae, with the resultant shortening of the esophagus and bunching up of the mucosa in the lumen.

On endoscopy, the esophagus appears narrow and friable with transient or fixed mucosal rings, strictures, and linear furrows. 

The diagnosis requires a biopsy with a histologic finding of >15–20 eosinophils per high-power field. An exclusion diet and steroids help in the management of this condition.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.3.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A pregnant woman complained of excessive vomiting and mild vaginal bleeding for 2 weeks at a period of gestation of 14 weeks. On examination, fundal height corresponds to 16 weeks and fetal heart sound is absent.  USG shows the presence of a snowstorm appearance. What is the management____
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of molar pregnancy and regardless of uterine size, molar evacuation by suction and curettage is usually the preferred treatment. 

With large moles, adequate anesthesia, sufficient intravenous access, and blood-banking support are imperative.

Intraoperative sonography is recommended to help ensure that the uterine cavity has been emptied.

Indication for hysterectomy in molar pregnancy:

  • Preferred for women who have completed their family.
  • In women >40 years, who are at high risk for GTN.

questions.text: The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are:

choices.text: Sulfur dioxide, smoke and suspended particles
Sulfur dioxide, lead and particulate matter

questions.solution:
The best indicators for routine monitoring of air pollution are sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

  • The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.
  • Air pollutants:
Pollutant Comments
Carbon monoxide From incomplete combustion of carbon-containing materials like fuel combustion, vehicles, industries, etc.
Sulphur dioxide Colorless gas with a sharp odor. Results from combustion of sulphur-containing fossil fuels, smelting of ores, etc. It is one of the main components of acid rain.
Lead Usually occupational and environmental sources.
Carbon dioxide Increase in global concentration above natural levels can increase temperature and affect climate adversely.
Hydrocarbons Cause photochemical smog.
Cadmium Results from volcanic action, waste incineration, zinc production, smoking, etc.
Hydrogen sulphide Produced in waste-water treatment plants, wood pulp production, coke production, etc.
Ozone Ground level ozone is one of the main constituents of photochemical smog.
Oxides of nitrogen  Most common form is nitric oxide. Produced from coal burning, road traffic and electricity generation. Affects lungs adversely.
Polyaromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) Produced by incomplete burning of wood or coal, vehicle exhausts, smoking, etc. PAHs are carcinogenic and mutagenic.
Particulate matter Mixture of solid and liquid, organic and inorganic matter. Major components are sulfates, nitrates, sodium chloride, mineral dust, black carbon and water.
  • Common indoor air pollutants include carbon monoxide, PAHs, nitrogen and sulphur oxides, pesticides, asbestos, lead, radon and other biological pollutants. Most these are from coal or fuel combustion. Pollutants like radon, lead, asbestos, etc. are from construction materials, paints and demolition.
  • Effects of indoor air pollution:
    • Lung infections including pneumonia, tuberculosis, ALRI
    • Stroke
    • Ischemic heart disease
    • COPD
    • Lung, laryngeal, nasopharyngeal cancers
    • Pregnancy problems like low birth weight
  • Indicators of air pollution:
    • Sulphur dioxide is one of the best indicators of air pollution
    • Smoke or soiling index: A known volume of air is filtered through a white filter paper under specified conditions and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter
    • Grit and dust measurement are another indicator of air pollution
    • Co-efficient of haze is a factor used in assessment of the amount of smoke or other aerosol in air
    • Air pollution index is an arbitrary index which takes into account one or more pollutants as a measure of pollution severity
    • Suspended particle matter (SPM) is another indicator widely used
  • In India, National Air Quality Programme sponsored by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) is the main mode of monitoring air pollution.

questions.text: A study was conducted on the effectiveness of a keto diet for weight loss. Weight of the participants was measured before starting the keto diet and after 1 month of the keto diet.  Which of the following is the most appropriate test to test the statistical significance of the change in weight?
questions.solution:
Since the effect of keto diet is checked on the same individuals, before and after the keto diet, therefore the test used is paired t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: You are a resident assisting in vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was uncomplicated.  The mother gives birth to a male newborn at term, who does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The heart rate is 98 beats/minute. Respiration is not noted. What should your next step be?
questions.solution:
A term neonate who remains apnoeic despite stimulation should be given positive pressure ventilation by a bag and mask. 
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100, PPV is provided with bag and mask and SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate still remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

questions.text: An intern collects all the given materials to assist in a procedure in the ICU. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
From the materials which have been gathered by the senior resident, it can be inferred that he would be performing a central venous catheterization. 

The materials are as follows according to their numbers in the given image.

  1. A syringe with a local anesthetic
  2. Scalpel in case venous cutdown is needed
  3. Sterile gel for ultrasound guidance
  4. Introducer needle (here 18 Ga) on the syringe with saline to detect backflow of blood upon vein penetration
  5. Guidewire
  6. Tissue dilator
  7. An indwelling catheter (here 16 Ga)
  8. Additional fasteners, and corresponding surgical thread
  9. The final dressing to be applied

The catheter can be inserted into any of the following veins - Internal jugular veins, subclavian vein, external jugular veins, and femoral vein.

Preferred sites in special considerations :

  • Severe bleeding diatheses - Internal/external jugular vein
  • Severe emphysema - Internal jugular
  • Emergency transvenous cardiac pacing - Right internal jugular
  • Trauma patients (neck immobilised) - Subclavian/Femoral

Indications of central venous catheterization include

  • Central venous pressure monitoring
  • Pulmonary artery catheterization and monitoring
  • Transvenous cardiac pacing
  • Temporary hemodialysis
  • Drug administration (concentrated vasoactive drugs, hyperalimentation, chemotherapy, agents irritating peripheral veins, prolonged antibiotic therapy)
  • Rapid infusion of fluids (Trauma, major surgery)
  • Aspiration of air emboli
  • Inadequate peripheral venous access
  • Sampling site for repeated blood testing

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the surgical OPD after she notices a lump while bathing. On examination, the lump is painless and located in the upper left quadrant of the left breast. Skin tethering and nipple retraction are present. There have been no similar complaints in her family. Mammography shows the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a 32-year-old woman with a painless lump showing skin tethering and puckering along with mammography showing egg-shell calcification is most likely to be traumatic fat necrosis.

Traumatic fat necrosis :

  • Traumatic fat necrosis may be acute or chronic and
  • It usually occurs in stout, middle-aged women.
  • Following a blow, or even indirect violence (e.g. contraction of the pectoralis major), a lump, often painless, appears.
  • A history of trauma is not diagnostic as this may merely have drawn the patient’s attention to a pre-existing lump
  • This may mimic a carcinoma, even displaying skin tethering and nipple retraction, and biopsy is required for diagnosis.
  • Fat necrosis is a frequently encountered cause of benign calcifications, particularly when there is a history of trauma or previous surgery. It presents as ‘egg shell’ calcifications within the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications associated with areas of scarring.

Radiological findings in other diseases of the breast :

  • Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma.
  • Broken-needle type of calcification is seen in duct ectasia.
  • Tea-cup calcification is seen in fibrocystic disease.

Microcalcifications are frequently encountered on routine screening mammograms. Some calcifications have a characteristic benign appearance and require no further action.

Mammography findings in invasive carcinoma of the breast :

Carcinomas typically appear as ill-defined or spiculate masses on mammography

Popcorn calcification:

Broken-needle type of calcification 

Tea-cup calcification-On a lateral magnification view, layering of calcific fluid contained within microcysts can be appreciated, producing a characteristic ‘teacup’ appearance.

Invasive carcinoma of the breast : An ill-defined mass lying centrally in the breast, containing some microcalcifications. Calcifications, representing DCIS, may be found in association with invasive carcinoma

questions.text: Spasmodic pain during dysmenorrhoea is attributed to:
questions.solution:
Spasmodic pain is attributed to myometrial contractions, due to increased PGF2α, which is secreted under the effect of Progesterone.

Note that Progesterone is mainly secreted after ovulation, by the corpus luteum. Therefore, whenever ovulation is absent (Anovulatory cycles), menstruation is not accompanied by spasmodic pain (i.e painless bleeding in anovulatory cycles)

Congestive dysmenorrhoea is explained by pelvic venous congestion, which can be seen on Doppler Ultrasound.

Vasopressin and endothelin, by increasing PGF2α secretion also contribute to dysmenorrhoea.

questions.text: Which technique of female sterilization is portrayed in the following image?
questions.solution:
The technique of sterilization portrayed in the image is the Pomeroy technique.

The most popular technique of tubal ligation is the Pomeroy technique.

Procedure :

  • The fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut (any rapidly absorbing sutures) and excised.
  • There should be an adequate margin between the suture and the cut end to prevent the cut ends of the tube from slipping out of the suture.
  • The cut ends of the tube are inspected to visualize the tubal lumen; this confirms resection of a full thickness of the tube.
  • As the tubal stumps heal, the suture absorbs and the ends fall apart

The operation is simple, requires short hospitalization and is surgically reversible.

The failure rate is only 0.4% and it is mainly due to spontaneous canalization.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male was found in a disoriented state in his apartment by his son. He has a 30-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a dry tongue and appears extremely dehydrated. Serum glucose is found to be 848mg/gl.  Identify the true feature from the following regarding the patient's condition.

choices.text: Arterial blood gas analysis shows pH of 7.4
High anionic gap metabolic acidosis is noted

questions.solution:
The clinical condition of the elderly patient suggests that he is experiencing a hyperglycemic hyperosmolar state (HHS), a complication of Type 2 diabetes mellitus (Type 2 DM). Arterial blood gas analysis showing a pH of 7.4 can be a true feature of HHS.

HHS:

Features

  • Acute complication of Type 2 DM
  • Elderly patients
  • H/O polyuria for several weeks and decreased oral intake
  • Mentally confused
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered sensorium and coma

Investigation

  • Blood sugar level - 600 – 1200 mg %
  • Serum osmolality > 350 mOsm / L
  • Prerenal azotemia – Due to dehydration
  • Pseudohyponatremia
  • No ketoacidosis

Management

  • Fluid replacement
  • IV regular insulin
  • SC Heparin – to prevent venous thrombosis

Other options:

Kussmaul respiration(breathing) and high anionic gap metabolic acidosis are features of Diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: The earliest sign observed in tuberculosis of the bladder by cystoscopy is ____.
questions.solution:
The earliest sign of tuberculosis of the bladder observed by cystoscopy is pallor of the mucosa around the ureteric orifice due to submucous edema. Subsequently, tubercles may be seen.

In long-standing cases, there is marked fibrosis and the capacity of the bladder is greatly reduced (thimble bladder).

Hunner's patch or Hunner's ulcer is observed in interstitial cystitis.

questions.text: A surgery resident during the rounds advised the intern to monitor the burns patient for adequate fluid resuscitation and also instructed him to give a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight if the patient showed signs of hypoperfusion. All of the following are indications to give bolus fluid except _______
questions.solution:
A high hematocrit (not low) is an indicator of hypoperfusion.

Urine output is the best measure to monitor for the adequacy of fluid resuscitation. Urine output should be between 0.5 and 1.0 mL/kg body weight per hour.

  • If the urine output is below this, the infusion rate should be increased by 50%.
  • If the urine output is inadequate and the patient is showing signs of hypoperfusion, then a bolus of 10 mL/kg body weight should be given.

Signs of hypoperfusion include,

  1. Restlessness with tachycardia,
  2. Cool peripheries and
  3. High hematocrit

questions.text:
A male patient came with the following laboratory test results given below. Which of the following combinations of drugs is ideal for the condition based on the laboratory results?

HCV RNA: Positive

IgG anti-HCV: Positive
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and blood investigations showing the presence of HCV RNA and IgG anti-HCV are suggestive of chronic hepatitis C. Among the given options, the combination of sofosbuvir and velpatasvir would be ideal for this condition. 

The goal of treatment is to eradicate HCV RNA during the therapy and to document that the virus remains undetectable for at least 12 weeks after completion of therapy. This is known as a sustained virological response at 12 weeks (SVR12). The combination of Sofosbuvir (polymerase inhibitor) and Velpatasvir (NS5A inhibitor) has now been approved as the first-line treatment of hepatitis C genotypes 1-6, irrespective of whether or not the patient has previously received any treatment or has cirrhosis. Any patient with chronic hepatitis C who has detectable HCV RNA in the serum, irrespective of ALT/AST levels, is a candidate for this treatment. 

Sofosbuvir-ribavirin combination is inferior to sofosbuvir-velpatasvir drug combination therapy. Other options are not used in hepatitis C management.

questions.text: The given USG of lung shows:
questions.solution:
The given image shows the "Seashore sign" seen in M-mode imaging of the normal lung.

In the M-mode of USG, the motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves', and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture is one that resembles waves crashing in onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and is present in a normal lung.

Other options:

Stratosphere sign: M-mode shows a linear pattern below the pleural line. It is also called "Barcode sign". This is seen in pneumothorax. 

Mirror Image artifact: This is seen when there is a highly reflective surface(eg: Diaphragm) in the path of the primary beam.

There is no named sign called "Troposphere sign".

questions.text: A multiparous woman is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation.  On examination, the uterus appears asymmetrical, fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. In fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. The fetal presentation in this patient will be__
questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of the transverse lie. The fetal presentation in a transverse lie is shoulder presentation.

  • The most common cause of transverse lies is prematurity.
  • The most common cause of transverse lies in term pregnancy is placenta previa.
  • The most common cause of cord prolapse is transverse lie.
  • Hand prolapse is frequently seen in transverse lie.
  • The transverse lie is managed by the caesarean section.
  • Management of neglected shoulder presentation is caesarean section.
  • Management of 1st twin with a transverse lie is cesarean section.
  • Management of 2nd twin with a transverse lie is Internal podalic version.

questions.text: A 6-week-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of noisy breathing, present since a few days after birth. It subsides with prone positioning and increases with crying. The observation made on direct laryngoscopy is shown in the image below. The stridor present in this patient would be ____
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia:

It is the most common congenital abnormality of the larynx and the most common cause of stridor in children. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. The presentation is just after birth and subsides by 2 years. Stridor improves(decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. Laryngomalacia leads to the collapse of supraglottic structures during inspiration which results in airway obstruction.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self-corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of the thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presents with pain and swelling in her left hand for 3 months. A radiograph of the swelling is shown. Which of the following can be expected to be observed in histopathology?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of osteoclastoma(Giant cell tumor). Histopathological examination shows mononuclear tumor cells in osteoclastoma.

A giant cell tumor is a locally aggressive benign bone tumor that is characterized by the presence of multinucleated osteoclast-type giant cells. It is most commonly seen in the age of 30-50 years.

These tumors affect the epiphysis of long bones. The affected sites are the distal femur and proximal tibia. It may present as pathological fractures and arthritis-like symptoms. The neoplastic cells are derived from primitive osteoblast precursors that express high levels of RANKL. This facilitates the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their maturation. The lack of a normal feedback mechanism between osteoblasts and osteoclasts results in aggressive bone resorption. 

The gross appearance of the tumor shows a red-brown mass with cystic degeneration. Histopathological examination shows oval mononuclear tumor cells and abundant osteoclast-type giant cells with numerous nuclei. Reactive bone may be present at the periphery.

Treatment comprises curettage and adjuvant therapy with RANKL inhibitors like denosumab.

Other options:

Option B: Sheets of small round blue cells with scanty cytoplasm are seen in the histopathological examination of Ewing's sarcoma. Homer-Wright rosettes signify the neuroectodermal origin of the tumor. It consists of clusters of round cells with a central fibrillary core.HPE is shown below:

 

Option C: Malignant chondrocytes with abundant clear cytoplasm and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells are seen in clear-cell chondrosarcoma.

Option D: Malignant osteoblasts producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralized bone along with extensive necrosis and intravascular invasion are seen in osteosarcoma.

questions.text: Spiegelberg’s criteria is for ______
questions.solution:
Spiegelberg’s criteria is for the diagnosis of ovarian ectopic preganacy.

The criteria includes:

  • The ipsilateral tube is intact and distinct from the ovary
  • The ectopic pregnancy occupies the ovary
  • The ectopic pregnancy is connected by the uteroovarian ligament to the uterus
  • Ovarian tissue can be demonstrated histologically in the placental tissue.

Salphingo – oopherectomy is the definitive surgery.

Other criteria in ectopic:

  • Primary abdominal: Studiford's criteria
  • Cervical pregnancy: Rubin's criteria

questions.text: Mr. Raju presents to the clinic with a history of discharge from the anal region for the past 2 weeks. He underwent drainage of the ischiorectal abscess 2 months back. Clinical examination and imaging reveal the presence of a suprasphincteric perianal fistula. How will you manage this patient?
questions.solution:
Seton’s technique is used in the management of high lying anal fistula.

A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis.

Cutting Seton

A cutting seton has been used as a staged fistulectomy, especially in high trans-sphincteric fistulas. After the seton is passed during the primary surgery, it has to be tightened at regular intervals, till it cuts through completely.

Loose seton

In this method, the seton is placed to maintain drainage and create scar tissue around the sphincter so that its edges do not retract after cutting.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with low backache and weight loss.He has progressive difficulty in urination and had an episode of urinary retention 2 days back which was relieved by catheterization.PSA was done which was  5.2 ng/ml and X Ray LS spine shows osteoblastic changes. What is the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical details with elevated PSA and blastic changes in LS spine suggest a diagnosis of carcinoma prostate.The Xray findings can be metastasis to the bone.

Carcinoma of the prostate:

  • It is the most common form of cancer affecting men, usually older than 50 years of age.
  • The growth and survival of prostate cancer cells depend on androgens, which bind to the androgen receptor (AR) and induce the expression of pro-growth and pro-survival genes.
  • Men with germline mutations of the tumor suppressor BRCA2 have a 20-fold increased risk of prostate cancer.
  • Other acquired mutations include TPRSS2-ETS fusion genes and mutations or deletions that activate the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway.
  • Prostatic Intraepithelial Neoplasia(PIN) has been described as the precursor lesion of carcinoma prostate.
  • Approximately 70% of carcinomas of the prostate arise in the peripheral zone of the gland, classically in a posterior location.
  • Grossly, malignant tissue is gritty and firm in consistency (in contrast to the spongy appearance of benign tissue) and thus more readily palpable on digital rectal examination.
  • Histologically, most lesions are adenocarcinomas that shows small crowded glands lined by a single layer of neoplastic cells with mild to moderate degree of pleomorphism. The outer basal cell layer is absent.
  • Immunohistochemically, basal cell markers are absent and α-methyl acyl-coenzyme A-racemase (AMACR) positive.
  • Grading of prostate cancer by the modified Gleason system correlates with pathologic stage and prognosis.

PSA is a product of prostatic epithelium secreted in the semen. Normally, only minute amounts of PSA circulates in the serum. Older men have a higher serum PSA level than younger men, so the normal range varies with age.

Measurement of serum PSA levels is widely used to assist the diagnosis, prognosis, and management of prostate cancer.

Age Upper age-specific PSA(ng/mL)
40–49 yrs 2.5
50–59 yrs 3.5
60–69 yrs 4.5
70–79 yrs 6.5
