questions.text: Which of the following procedures is not done as part of a damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Intra-medullary nailing is undertaken as a part of definitive surgery, not damage control surgery (DCS). 

DCS is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and followed by definite surgery later. It aims to coordinate staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

Orthopaedic damage control surgery is restricted to the debridement of severe open fractures, quick temporary splinting or stabilization of long bone fractures, and, when necessary, the decompression of limb compartment syndrome.

After the initial steps of DCS, definitive surgery involving intra-medullary nailing may be done.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indicator of body fat?
questions.solution:
The Reid index is normally 0.4. It is defined as the ratio of the thickness of the submucosal gland layer to that of the bronchial wall. It is increased in chronic bronchitis.

Other options are indicators of body fat.

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

  • Body weight:  +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:
    • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
    • Ponderal index : Weight(g) x 100/(Length in cm)3
    • Corpulence index:Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)
  • Broaca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 
  • Lorentz's formula 
    Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]
  • Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.
  • Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.
  • Total body water
  • Total body potassium
  • Body density

questions.text: According to Strasberg’s classification of bile duct injuries, injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct with bile leak is:
questions.solution:
Injury to the right aberrant posterior sectoral duct associated with bile leak is classified as Strasberg’s type C injury.

The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define bile duct injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases will NOT present with skin lesions on the shin?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is unlikely to present with skin lesions on shin. Myxedema (severe hypothyroidism) and pretibial myxedema are different entities. Pretibial myxedema is the infiltrative dermopathy (mucin deposition) seen over shin in Grave's disease, a type of hyperthyroidism. 

Other options :

  • Diabetes: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is classically seen on anterior leg.
  • Sarcoidosis: Erythema nodosum may be seen on anterior leg.

questions.text: Hepatitis D superinfection and coinfection may be differentiated using which of the following markers?
questions.solution:
IgM anti-HBc may help in differentiating hepatitis D coinfection and superinfection.

HBV/HDV co-infection occurs due to simultaneous infection with both HBV and HDV. The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates recent infection. Therefore, in coinfection with acute HBV and HDV, IgM anti-HBc will be detectable.

Whereas, superinfection is the HDV infection of an individual chronically infected with HBV. Therefore, in acute HDV superinfection over chronic HBV infection, IgM anti-HBc will not be detectable, however, IgG anti-HBc will be present.

questions.text:
A patient with shortness of breath is diagnosed to have acute pulmonary edema. His chest X-ray, on PA view, revealed lines in the periphery of the lungs that are perpendicular to the pleural surface. What are these lines?

PA view- Postero-anterior view
questions.solution:
Lines in the periphery of the lungs that are perpendicular to the pleural surface in a patient with pulmonary edema are suggestive of Kerley B lines.

Kerley lines are septal lines that are seen when the interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium become prominent. It can be due to lymphatic engorgement or edema of the connective tissues of the interlobular septa. These are usually seen when the pulmonary capillary wedge pressure reaches 20-25 mmHg.

Types of Kerley lines: 

Kerley A lines- They extend radially from the hilum to the upper lobes and cross the normal vascular markings. These are oblique lines that are <1 mm thick, 2-6cm long, and course towards the hila. They represent thickened interlobular septa that contain lymphatic connections between the perivenous and bronchoarterial lymphatics in the lung parenchyma. The best modality for the demonstration of Kerley A-lines is HRCT.

Kerley B-lines - These are seen in the periphery of the lungs and are seen perpendicular to the pleural surface. These are thin 1-2 cm long lines. These are usually seen at the lung bases and represent thickened subpleural interlobular septa.

Kerley C-lines - These are short lines that do not reach the pleura (i.e. not B or D lines) and do not course radially away from the hila (i.e. not A-lines).

Kerley D-lines - These are the same as Kerley B lines, except that they are seen on lateral chest radiographs in the retrosternal air gap (the lucent area behind the sternum).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to the OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score.
questions.solution:
The obstetric score of the patient is G4 P1 A2 L1. 

The obstetric score is used to summarise the past obstetric history as follows:

  • G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one
  • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability 
    • This includes both live births and stillbirths
    • The current pregnancy is not included
  • A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages.
  • L - Living children

Multifetal pregnancies count as one for both gravida and para. A pregnant woman who delivers twins will be expressed as primipara.

The GTPAL system includes the following:

  • Gravida
  • Term (>37 weeks)
  • Preterm (20w - 36w 6d)
  • Abortions (<20 weeks)
  • Number of living children

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

questions.text: Which is the best time for surgery for hypospadias?
questions.solution:
Operations for hypospadiasis are routinely performed when the patient is between 6 and 18 months of age.

The commonest procedure for distal hypospadias is the ‘tubularized incised plate’ urethroplasty, while techniques that utilize the foreskin are commonly used for more proximal hypospadias.

Complications of hypospadias surgery:

  • urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)
  • Recurrence of chordee
  • Urethral stricture
  • Meatal stenosis
  • Infection
